encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. K.Johan Englande Sedicyon/Monk/Stephen Langton Nobylyte Clergye Cyvyle Order Dissymulacyon/Raymundus Privat Welth/Pandulphus Usurpid Powre/Pope Interpretour Omnes Una Commynnalte Cardynall Treason Veritas Imperyall Majestye Combined voice

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: To declare the powers and their force to enlarge
The scripture of God doth flow in most abundance;
And of sophisters the cautelous to discharge,
both Peter and Pawle maketh plenteous utterance;
How that all people should show their true allegiance
to their lawful king Christ Jesu doth consent,
Which to the high powers was ever obedient.
to show what I am I think it convenient:
Johan, King of Ynglond, the chronicles doth me call.
My grandfather was an emperor excellent,
My father a king by succession lineal,
A king my brother like as to him did fall
Rychard Curdelyon they called him in France,
Which had over enemies most fortunable chance.
by the will of God and his high ordinance,
in Yerlond and Walys, in Anjou and Normandye,
in Ynglond also, I have had the governance.
I have worn the crown and wrought victoriously,
And now do purpose by practice and by study
to reform the laws and set men in good order,
that true justice may be had in every border.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Then I trust your grace will weigh a poor widow's cause
Ungodly used as ye shall know in short clause.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Yea, that I will swear, if it be true and just.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: like as it beareth truth so let it be discussed.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then, gentle widow, tell me what the matter is.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Alas, your clergy hath done very sore amiss
in misusing me against all right and justice;
And for my more grief thereto they other entice.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Whom do they entice for to do the injury?

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Such as hath entered by false hypocrisy,
Much worse fruits having than hath the thorns unpleasant,
for they are the trees that God did never plant,
And, as Christ doth say, blind leaders of the blind.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Tell me whom thou meanest to satisfy my mind.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Such lubbers as hath disguised heads in their hoods,
Which in idleness do live by other men's goods:
Monks, canons, and nones in divers colour and shape,
both white, black and pied. God send there increase ill hap

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Let me know thy name or I go farther with thee.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Ynglond, sir, Ynglond my name is ye may trust me.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I marvel right sore how thou comest changed thus.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: What, you two alone? I will tell tales, by Jesus
And say that I see you fall here to butchery.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Avoid, lewd person, for thy words are ungodly.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I cry you mercy, sir, I pray you be not angry.
By my faith and troth, I cam hither to be merry.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Thou canst with thy mirth in no wis discontent me
so that thou powder it with wisdom and honest.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I am no spicier: by the mass, ye may believe me.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I speak of no spice, but of civil honest.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Ye spake of powder, by the Holy Trinity

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Not as thou takest it, of a gross capacity,
But as Saint Pawle meaneth unto the Collossians plain,
"So season your speech that it be without disdain".
Now, Ynglond, to thee: go thou forth with thy tale
And show the cause why thou lookest so wan and pale.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: I told you before the fault was in the clergy
that I, a widow, appear to you so barely.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Ye are a Wily what, and wander here full warily.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Why in the clergy? Do me to understand.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: for they take from me my cattle, house and land,
My woods and pastures with other commodities;
like as Christ did say to the wicked Pharisees,
"Pore widow's houses ye gross up by long prayers",
in side coats wandering like most disguised players.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: They are well at ease that hath such sooth sayers.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: They are thy children; thou oughtest to say them good.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Nay, bastards they are, unnatural by the rood
Since their beginning they were never good to me.
The wild boar of Rome God let him never to thee
like pigs they follow, in fantasies, dreams and lies,
And ever are fed with his vile ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Nay, sometime they eat both flans and pigeon pies.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: by the boar of Rome I trow thou meanest the Pope.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: I mean none other but him God give him a rope

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: And why dost thou thus compare him to a swine?

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: for that he and his to such beastliness incline.
They forsake Gods word which is most pure and clean,
And unto the laws of sinful men they lean.
like as the vile swine the most vile metes desire,
And hath great pleasure to wallow themselves in mire,
so hath this wild boar, with his church universal,
His sow with her pigs and monsters bestial,
Delight in men's draff and covetous lucre all.
Yea, appear the sylva the prophet did him call.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Hold your peace, ye whore, or else, by mass I trow,
I shall cause the Pope to curse thee as black as a crow.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: What art thou, fellow, that seem so bragging bold?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I am Sedition, that with the Pope will hold
so long as I have a hole within my breech.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Command this fellow to avoid, I you beseech,
for doubtless he hath done me great injury.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Avoid, lewd fellow, or thou shalt rue it truly.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I will not away for that same whithered witch;
She shall rather kiss where as it doth not itch.
Quodcumque ligaveris I trow will play such a part
that I shall abide in England, maugre your heart.
Tush, the Pope ableth me to subdue both king and kaiser.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Of that thou and I will common more at leisure.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Truly of the devil they are that do anything
to the subduing of any christen king.
for be he good or bade he is of Gods appointing:
The good for the good, the bad is for ill doing.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Of that we shall talk here after: say forth thy mind now
And show me how thou art thus become a widow.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: These vile popish swine hath clean exiled my husband.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: who is thy husband? tell me, good gentle Yngland.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: for sooth, God himself, the spouse of every sort
that seek him in faith to their soul's health and comfort.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: He is scant honest that so many wives will have.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I say hold your peace and stand aside like a knave
Is God exiled out of this region? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Yea, that he is, sir: it is much more pete.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: How cometh it to pass that he is thus abused?

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Ye know he abideth not where his word is refused,
for God is his word like as Saint John doth tell
in the beginning of his most blessed gospel.
The Pope's pigs may not abide this word to be heard,
Nor known of people, or had in any regard.
their eyes are so sore they may not abide the light,
And that bred so hard their galled gums may it not bite.
I, knowing your grace to have here the governance
by the gift of God, do knowledge my allegiance,
Desiring your grace to weigh such injuries
As I daily suffer by these same subtle spies.
And let me have right as ye are a rightful king,
Appointed of God to have such matter in doing;
for God willeth you to help the pore widow's cause,
As he by Essay protesteth in this same clause:
Seek right to poor, to the weak and fatherless,
Defend the widow when she is in distress.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I tell ye the woman is in great heaviness.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I may not in no wise leave thy right undiscussed,
for God hath set me, by his appointment just,
to further thy cause and to maintain thy right,
And therefore I will support the day and night.
so long as my simple life shall here endure,
I will see thee have no wrong, be fast and swear.
I will first of all call my nobility,
Dukes, earls and lords, each one in their degree;
Next them the clergy or fathers spiritual,
Archbishops, bishops, abbots and priors all;
Then the great judges and lawyers everyone,
so opening to them thy cause and pitiful moan,
by the means whereof I shall their minds understand.
if they help thee not myself will take it in hand
And set such a way as shall be to thy comfort.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Then for an answer I will shortly again resort.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Do, Ynglond, hardly, and thou shalt have remedy.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: God reward your Grace, I beseech him heartily,
And send you long days to govern this realm in peace.

body.stage: Go owt Ynglond and drese for Clargy.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Gramercy, Yngland, and send the plenteous increase.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Of babbling matters I trow it is time to cease.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Why dost thou call them babbling matters? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: for they are not worth the shaking of a perter
When the peers are gone: they are but dibble dabble.
I marvel ye can abide such bible babble.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Thou seemest to be a man of simple discretion.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Alas, that ye are not a priest to hear confession.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Why for confession? let me know thy fantasy.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Because that ye are a man so full of mercy,
Namely to women that weep with a heavy heart
When they in the church hath let but a little fart.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I perceive well now thou speakest all this in mockage
Because I take part with England's rightful heritage.
Say thou what thou wilt, her matter shall not perish.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: it is joy of him that women so can cherish.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: God hath me ordained in this same princely estate,
for that I should help such as be desolate.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: it is as great pity to see a woman weep
As it is to see a silly dodman crepe,
Or, as ye would say, a silly goose go barefoot.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Thou seemest by thy words to have no more wit than a coot.
I marvel thou art to England so unnatural:
Being her own child thou art worse than a best brutal.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I am not her child: I defy her, by the mass
I her son, quoth he I had rather she were headless.
Though I sometime be in England for my pastaunce,
Yet was I neither born here, in Spain, nor in France,
But under the Pope in the holy city of Rome,
And there will I dwell unto the day of doom.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: But what is thy name? Tell me yet once again.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: As I said afore, I am Sedition plain:
in every religion and monkish sect I reign,
Hiving you princes in scorn, hate and disdain.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I pray thee, good friend, tell me what is thy fashion.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Search and ye shall find in every congregation
that long to the Pope, for they are to me full swear,
And will be so long as they last and endure.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: If thou be a cloisterer, tell of what order thou art.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: in every estate of the clergy I play a part:
Sometime I can be a monk in a long side cowl;
Sometime I can be a none and look like an owl;
Sometime a cannon in a surplus fair and white;
A chapterhouse monk sometime I appear in sight;
I am over Sire Johan, sometime with a new shaven crown;
Sometime the person and sweep the streets with a side gown;
Sometime the bishop with a mitre and a cope;
A gray fryer sometime with cut shoes and a rope;
Sometime I can play the white monk, sometime the fryer,
The purgatory priest and every man's wife desire.
This company hath provided for me mort-main,
for that I might ever among their sort remain.
Yea, to go farther, sometime I am a cardinal,
Yea, sometime a pope, and then am I lord over all,
both in heaven and earth, and also in purgatory,
And do wear three crowns when I am in my glory.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: But what dost thou here in England? Tell me shortly.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I hold up the Pope as in other places many,
for his ambassador I am continually
in Sycell, in Naples, in Venys and Ytalye,
in Pole, Spruse, and Beme in Denmark and Lumbardye,
in Aragon, in Spain, in France, and in Germany,
in Ynglond, in Scotlond, and in other regions else.
for his holy cause I maintain traitors and rebels,
that no prince can have his people's obedience,
Except it doth stand with the Popes pre-eminence.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Get thee hence, thou knave, and most presumptuous wretch,
Or as I am true king thou shalt an halter stretch
we will thou know it our power is of God,
And therefore we will so execute the rod
that no lewd priest shall be able to maintain thee.
I see now they be at too much liberty;
we will short their horns if God send time and space.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Then I in England am like to have no place?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: no, that thou art not, and therefore avoid apace.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: by the holy mass, I must laugh to hear your grace
Ye suppose and think that ye could me subdue:
Ye shall never find your supposition true,
Though ye were as strong as Hector and Diomedes,
Or as valiant as ever was Achilles.
Ye are well content that bishops continue still?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: we are so in deed, if they their duty fulfil.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Nay then, good enough your authority and power
Shall pass as they will; they have sauce both sweet and sour.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: What meanest thou by that? Show me the intent this hour.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: They are Gods vicars: they can both save and lose.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Ah, thy meaning is that they may a prince depose.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: by the rood, they may, and that will appear by you.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Be the help of God, we shall see to that well enough.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Nay that ye cannot though ye had Argus eyes,
in abbeys they have so many subtle spies.
for ones in the year they have secret visitations,
And if any prince reform their ungodly factions,
Then two of the monks must forth to Rome by and by
With secret letters to avenge their injury.
for a thousand pound they shrink not in such matter,
And yet for the time the prince to his face they flatter.
I am ever more their guide and their advocate.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then with the bishops and monks thou art check mate.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I dwell among them and am one of their sort.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: for thy sake they shall of me have but small comfort;
Look where I find thee that place will I put down.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: What if ye do chance to find me in every town
Where as is founded any sect monastical.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I pray God I sink if I destroy them not all.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Well if ye so do yet know I where to dwell.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Thou art not skoymose thy fantasy for to tell.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Guess at a venture ye may chance the mark to hit.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Thy falsehood to show no man than thyself more fit.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Marry, in confession underneath benedicte

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Nay, tell it again that I may understand thee.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I say I can dwell when all other places fail me
And when I am there the priest may not bewray me.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Why, will ear confession such a secret traitor be?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: When all other fail he is so sure as steel.
Offend Holy Church and I warrant ye shall it feel;
for by confession the Holy Father knoweth
Throughout all Christendom what to his holiness growth.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: o where is Nobility that he might know this falsehood?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Nay he is become a maintainer of our godhead.
I know that he will do Holy Church no wrong
for I am his ghostly father and teacher among.
He believeth nothing but as Holy Church doth tell.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Why, giveth he no credence to Christ's holy gospel?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: no, sir, by the mass, but he calleth them heretics
that preach the gospel, and sedicious schismatics;
He teach them, vex them, from prison to prison he turn them,
He indicteth them, judge them, and in conclusion he burn them.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: we rue to hear this of our Nobility;
But in this behalf what sayst of the spirituality?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Of this I am swear to them to be no stranger
And specially when their honour is in danger.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: we trust our lawyers have no such wicked minds.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Yes, they many times are my most secret friends.
With faithful preachers they can play legerdemain,
And with false colours procure them to be slain.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I perceive this world is full of iniquity.
As God would have it, here cometh Nobility.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Doth he so in deed? by our Lord, then will I hence.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Thou saidest thou wouldst dwell where he keepeth residence.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Yea, but first of all I must change mine apparel
Unto a bishop to maintain with my quarrel,
to a monk or priest or to some holy fryer.
I should never else accomplish my desire.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Why, art thou going? Nay, brother, thou shalt not hence.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I would not be seen as I am for forty pence.
When I am religious I will return again.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Thou shalt tarry here, or I must put thee to pain.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I have a great mind to be a lecherous man
A vengeance take it I would say a religious man.
I will go and come so fast as ever I can.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Tush, dally not with me I say thou shalt abide.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Wean you to hold me that I shall not slip aside?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Make no more prating for I say thou shalt abide.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Stop not my passage: I must over see at the next tide.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I will ordain so: I trow thou shalt not over.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Tush, tush, I am sewer of ready passage at Dover.

body.stage: Her go owt Sedwsion and drese for Syvyll Ordere.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: The devil go with him The unthrifty knave is gone.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Trouble not yourself with no such dissolute person,
for ye know full well very little honest
Is got at their hands in every commonalty.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: This is but dalliance: ye do not speak as ye think.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: by my troth I do, or else I would I should sink.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then must I marvel at you of all men living.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Why marvel at me? Tell me your very meaning.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: for no man living is in more familiarity
With that wicked wretch, if it be true that he told me.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: What wretch speak ye of? for Jesus love intimate.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Of that presumptuous wretch that was with me here of late,
Whom you willed not to vex myself withal.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I know him not, I, by the way that my soul to shall

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Make it not so strange, for ye know him well I know.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Believe me if ye will, I know him not, I assure you.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Were ye never yet acquainted with Sedition?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Since I was a child both him and his condition
I ever hated for his iniquity.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: A clear token that is of true nobility.
But I pray to God we find it not other wise.
it was never well since the clergy wrought by practice
And left the scripture for men's imaginations,
Dividing themselves in so many congregations
Of monks, canons and friars of divers colours and factions.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I do trust your grace will be as loving now
As your predecessors have been to us before you.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I will sure weigh my love with your behavers;
like as ye deserve so will I bear you favours.
Clergy, mark it well; I have more to you to say
Than, as the saying is, the priest did speak a Sunday.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Ye will do us no wrong, I hope, nor injury.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: no, I will do you right in seeing you do your duty.
we know the cautels of your subtle company.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: if ye do us wrong we shall seek remedy.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Yea, that is the cast of all your company.
When kings correct you for your acts most ungodly
to the pope sitting in the chair of pestilence
Ye run, to remain in your concupiscence.
Thus set ye at naught all princely pre-eminence,
Subduing the order of dew obedience.
But within a while I shall so abate your pride
that to your puppet ye shall neither run nor ride,
But ye shall be glad to seek to me your prince
for all such matters as shall be within this province,
like as God willeth you by his scripture evident.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: to the Church I trust ye will be obedient?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: no matter to you whether I be so or no.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Yes, marry, is it, for I am sworn thereunto:
I toke a great oath when I was dubbed a knight
Ever to defend the Holy Churches right.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Yea, and in her quarrel ye ought unto death to fight.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: like backs, in the dark ye always take your flight,
Flittering in fancies, and ever abhor the light.
I rue it in heart that you, Nobility,
should thus bind yourself to the great captivity
Of bloody Babylon the ground and mother of whoredom
The Romish Church I mean, more vile than ever was Sodom,
And to say the truth a mete spouse for the find.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: your grace is fare gone: God send you a better mind.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Hold your peace, I say, ye are a little too fat.
in a while, I hope, ye shall be leaner somewhat.
we shall look to you and to Civil Order also:
Ye walk not so secret but we know where about ye goo.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Why, your grace hath no cause with me to be displeased.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: All things considered we have small cause to be pleased.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: I beseech your grace to grant me a word or two.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Speak on your pleasure and your hole mind also.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Ye know very well to set all things in order
I have much ado and many things pass from me
for your common wealth, and that in every border,
for offices, for lands, for law and for liberty:
And for transgressors I appoint the penalty
that cites and towns may stand in quietus peace,
that all theft and murder with other vice may cease.
If I have chanced for want of circumspection
to pass the limits of right and equity,
I submit myself unto your graces correction,
Desiring pardon of your benignity.
I wot I may fall through my fragility,
Therefore I pray you tell me what the matter is,
And amends shall be where as I have done amiss.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Against amendment no reasonable man can be.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: that sentence riseth out of an high charity.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Now that ye are here assembled all together,
Amongst other things ye shall first of all consider
that my displeasure reboundeth onto you all.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: to you none of us is prejudicial.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I shall prove it, yes. How have ye used England?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: But as it becommeth us so fare as I understand.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Yes, the pore woman complaineth her grievously,
And not without a cause, for she hath great injury.
I must see to it, there is no remedy,
for it is a charge given me from God almighty.
How say ye, Clergy, appeareth it not so to you?

sp.speaker: Clergye
K.Johan
sp.l: Then you, Nobility, will affirm it, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Ye, that I will, sir, so long as my life endure.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: And you, Civil Order, I think will grant the same?

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Undoubted, sir, yea; else were it to me great shame.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then for England's cause I will be somewhat plain.
it is you, Clergy, that hath her in disdain.
With your Latina hours, ceremonies and popely plays.
in her more and more Gods holy word decays,
And them to maintain unreasonable is the spoil
Of her lands, her goods, and of her pore childer's toil.
Reckon first your tithes, your devotions and your offerings,
Mortuaries, pardons, bequests and other things,
Besides that ye cache for hallowed bells and purgatory,
for jewels, for relics, confession and courts of bawdry,
for legacies, trentals with scalacely masses,
Whereby ye have made the people very asses:
And over all this ye have brought in a rabble
Of Latina mummers and sects deceivable
Even to devour her and eat her up attonnys.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: you would have no church, I wean, by these sacred bones.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Yes, I would have a church, not of disguised shavelings,
But of faithful hearts and charitable doings;
for when Christ's church was in her highest glory
She knew neither these sects nor their hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Yes, I will prove it by David substantially:

l.foreign: Astitit Regina a dextris tuis in vestitu

sp.l: A queen, saith David, on thy right hand, lord, I see,
Apparelled with gold and compassed with diversity.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: What is your meaning by that same scripture? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: This queen is the Church which through all Christian regions
Is beautiful, decked with many holy religions:
Monks, canons and friars, most excellent divines,
As Grandy Montensers and other Benedictines,
Premonstratensers, Bernardes and Gylbertynys,
Jacobytes, Minors, White Carmes and Augustines,
Sanbonites, Cluniackes, with holy Carthusyans,
Hermits and Anchors, with most mighty Rodyans,
Crucifers, Lucifers, Brigettes, Ambrosyanes,
Stellifers, Ensifers, with Purgatoryanes,
Sophyanes, Indianes and Camaldulensers,
Jesuits, Joannytes, with Clarimontensers,
Clarynes and Columbynes, Templars, New Ninivytes,
Rufyanes, Tercyanes, Lorytes and Lazarytes,
Hungaryes, Teutonyckes, Hospitalers, Honofrynes,
Basyles and Bonhams, Sclavons and Celestynes,
Paulynes, Hieronymytes, and Monks of Josaphathes Valley,
Fulygynes, Flamynes, with Brethren of the Black Alley,
Donates and Dimysynes, with Canons of Saint Mark,
Vestals and Monyals, a world to hear them bark,
Abbots and doctors, with bishops and cardinals,
Arch deacons and priests, as to their fortune falls.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Methinketh your first text standeth nothing with your reason,
for in David's time were no such sects of religion.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: David meaneth virtues by the same diversity,
As in the said psalm it is evident to see
And not monkish sects; but it is ever your cast
for your advancement the Scriptures for to wrest.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Of our holy father in this I take my ground,
which hath authority the Scriptures to expound.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Nay, he presumeth the Scriptures to confound.
Neither thou nor the Pope shall do pore England wrong,
I being governor and king her people among
While you for lucre set forth your popish laws
yourselves to advance ye would make us pick straws.
Nay, hypocrits, nay we will not be scorned so
Of a sort of knaves. we shall look you otherwise too.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Sir, your spirits are moved I perceive by your language.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I wonder that you for such vain popish baggage
Can suffer England to be impoverished
And mad a beggar; ye are very ill advised.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I marvel greatly that ye say thus to me.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: for doubtless ye do not as becommeth Nobility;
Ye spare neither lands nor goods, but all ye give
to these cormorants; it would any good man grieve
to see your madness, as I would God should save me.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Sir, I suppose it good to build a perpetuity
for me and my friends to be prayed for evermore.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Tush, it is madness all to despair in God so sore
And to think Christ's death to be insufficient.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Sir, that I have done was of a good intent.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: The intent is naught which hath no sewer ground.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: If you continue ye will Holy Church confound.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Nay, no Holy Church, nor faithful congregation,
But an heap of adders of Antichrists generation.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: it pitieth me much that ye are to them so hard.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: it pitieth me more that ye them so much regard.
They destroy men's souls with damnable superstition,
And decay all realms by maintenance of sedition.
Ye would wonder to know what proof I have of this.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Well amendment shall be where anything is amiss,
for, undoubted, God doth open such things to princes
As to none other men in the Christian provinces
And therefore we will not in this with your Grace contend.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: no, but with Gods grace we shall our misdeeds amend.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: for all such forfeits as your princely majesty
for your own person or realm can prove by me,
I submit myself to you, both body and goods.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: we pity you now, considering your repentant modes,
And our gracious pardon we grant you upon amendment.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: God preserve your Grace and Majesty excellent

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Arise, Clergy, arise, and ever be obedient,
And as God commandeth you take us for your governor.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: by the grace of God, the Pope shall be my ruler.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: What say ye, Clergy? who is your governor?

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: ha, did I stumble? I said my prince is my ruler.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I pray to our Lord this obedience may endure.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I will not break it ye may be fast and sure.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then come hither all three: ye shall know more of my mind.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Our king to obey the Scripture doth us bind.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Ye shall first be sworn to God and to the crown
to be true and just in every city and town,
And this to perform set hand and kiss the book.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: With the wife of Loth we will not backward lock
Nor turn from our oath, but ever obey your grace.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then will I give you your charges here in place
And accept you all to be of our high council.
to be faith full then ye us more straightly compel.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: for the love of God look to the state of England
Let no enemy hold her in miserable bond.
See you defend her as it becommeth nobility,
See you instruct her according to your degree,
Furnish her you with a civil honest.
Thus shall she flourish in honour and great plenty.
With godly wisdom your matters so conveye
that the commonalty the powers may obey,
And ever be ware of that false thief Sedition,
Which poiseneth all realms and bring them to perdition.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Sir, for such wretches we will be so circumspect
that neither their falsed nor guile shall us infect.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I warrant you, sir, no, and that shall well appear.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: we will so provide if any of them come here
to disturb the realm they shall be full glad to flee.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Well, your promise includeth no small difficult:
But I put the case that this false thief Sedition
should come to you three and call himself Religion:
Might he not under the pretence of holiness
Cause you to consent to much ungodliness?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: He shall never be able to do it verily.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: God grant ye be not deceived by hypocrisy.
I say no more, I. in sheep's apparel some walk
And seem religious that deceivably can caulk.
Beware of such hypocrits as the kingdom of heaven from man
Do hyde for advantage, for they deceive now and then.
Well I leave you here; each man consider his duty.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: With Gods leave, no fault shall be in this company.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Come, Civil Order, ye shall go hence with me.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: At your commandment I will gladly wait upon ye.

body.stage: Here Kyng Johan and Sivile Order go owt: and Syvile Order drese hym for Sedewsyon.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Methink the king is a man of a wonderful wit.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Nay, say that he is of a vengeable crafty wit,
Then shall ye be sure the truth of the thing to hit.
Hard ye not how he of the Holy Church did rail?
His extreme threatenings shall little him avail:
I will work such ways that he shall of his purpose fail.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: it is meet a prince to say somewhat for his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Yea, but it is too much to rail so without measure.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Well, let every man speak like as he hath a cause.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Why do ye say so? it is time for me then to pause.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: This will I say, sir, that he is so noble a prince
As this day reigneth in any Christian province.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Marry, it appeareth well by that he won in France

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Well, he lost not there so much by martial chance,
But he gate much more in Scotland, Ireland and Wales.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Yea, God sped us well: Christmas songs are merry tales

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Ye disdain such matter as ye know full evident.
Are not both Ireland and Wales to him obedient?
Yes, he holdeth them both in peaceable possession,
And because I will not from your tall make digression
for his land in France he giveth but little force,
Hiving to England all his love and remorse;
And Anjou he gave to Artur his nephew in change.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Our changes are such that an abbey turneth to a grange.
we are so handled we have scarce either horse or male.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: He that doth hate me the worse will tell my tale.
it is your fashion such kings to discommend
As your abuses reform or reprehend.
you priests are the cause that Chronicles doth defame
so many princes and men of notable name,
for you take upon you to right them evermore;
And therefore King Johan is like to rue it sore
When ye write his time for vexing of the clergy.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I marvel ye take his part so earnestly.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: it becommeth Nobility his princes fame to preserve.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: if he continue we are like in a while to starve:
He demandeth of us the tenth part of our living.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I think it is then for some necessary thing.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Marry to recover that he hath lost in France,
As Normandy dukedom and his land beyond Orleaunce.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: And think ye not that a matter necessary?

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: no, sir, by my troth, he taking it of the clergy.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Ye could be content that he should take it of us?

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Yea, so that he would spare the clergy, by sweet Jesus
This taking of us might soon grow to a custom,
And then Holy Church might so be brought to thralldom,
Which hath been ever from temporal princes free
As touching tribute or other captivity.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: He that defendeth you ought to have part of your goods.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: He hath the prayers of all them that hath hoods.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Why, is that enough to help him in his war?

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: The Church he may not of liberty debar.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Did not Christ himself pay tribute unto Caesar?
if he paid tribute, so ought his holy vicar.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: to hear ye reason so indiscreetly I wonder.
Ye must consider that Christ that time was under,
But his vicar now is above the princes all;
Therefore be ware ye do not to heresy fall.
Ye ought to believe as Holy Church doth teach you,
And not to reason in such high matters now.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I am unlearned, my wits are soon confounded.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Then leave such matters to men more deeply grounded.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: But how will ye do for the oath that ye have take?

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: The keys of the Church can all such matters off shake.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: What call ye those keys? I pray you heartily, tell me

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Our Holy Fathers power and his high authority.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Well, I can no more say: ye are too well learned for me.
My business is such that here now I must leave ye.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I must hence also so fast as ever may be,
to sue unto Rome for the Churches liberty.

body.stage: Go owt Nobylyte and Clargy. Here Sedycyon cummyth in.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Have in once again, in spite of all mine enemies,
for they cannot drive me from all men's companies;
And though it were so that all men would forsake me,
Yet doubt I it not but some good women would take me.
I look for fellows that here should make some sport.
I marvel it is so long ere they resort.
by the mass, I wean the knaves are in the briars,
Or else they are fallen in to some order of friars.
Nay, shall I guess right? They are gone into the stews.
I hold ye my neck anon we shall hear news.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: List, for Gods passion I trow her cometh some hog-herd
Calling for his pigs: such a noise I never herd
Here come Dissimulacy on singing of the Litany.

l.foreign: Sa n cte Francisse, ora pro nobis.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Hear ye not? Cock's soul, what meaneth this hypocrite knave?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Pater noster I pray God bring him soon to his grave;
Qui es in celis with an vengeable sanctification
Or else Holy Church shall never thrive, by Saint Peter.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Tell me, good fellow, makest thou this prayer for me?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Ye are as fierce as though ye had broke your nose at the buttery.
I meddle not with thee, but here to good saints I pray,
Against such enemies as will Holy Church decay.
A Johanne Rege iniquo, libera nos, Domine.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Leave, I say, or by the mass, I will make you groan.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: If thou be gentle, I pray thee, let me alone.
for within a while my devotion will be gone.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: And wherefore dost thou pray here so bitterly,
Mumbling thy Pater noster and chanting the Litany?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: for that Holy Church might save her patrimony,
And to have of King Johan a triumphant victory.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: And why of King Johan? Doth he vex you so sore?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: both churches and abbeys he oppresseth more and more,
And take of the clergy it is unreasonable to tell.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Out with the Pope's bulls, then, and curse him down to hell.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Tush, man, we have done so, but all that will not help.
He regardeth no more the Pope than he doth a whelp.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Well, let him alone; for that will I give him a scalp.
But what art thou called of thine own monkish nation?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Keep it in counsel: Dane Davy Dissimulation.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: What, Dissimulation? Cokes soul, mine old acquaintance

l.foreign: Par me faye, mon amye,je suis tote ad voutre plesaunce.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Gramercies, good friend, with all my very heart.
I trust we shall talk more freely or we depart.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Why, villain whoreson Knowest not thy cousin Sedition.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: I have ever loved both thee and thy condition.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Thou must needs, I trow, for we come of two brethren:
if thou remember, our fathers were on man's children
Thou comest of Falsed, and I of Privy Treason.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Then Infidelity our grandfather is by reason.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Marry, that is true, and his beginner Antichrist,
The great Pope of Rome or first vain popish priest.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Now welcome, cousin, by the way that my soul shall to

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Gramercy, cousin, by the holy bishop Benno.
Thou keepest thy old wont; thou art still an abbey mann.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: to hold all things up I play my part now and then.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Why, what manner of office hast thou within the abbey?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Of all religions I keep the church door key.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Then of a likelihood thou art their general porter.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Nay, of monks and canons I am the subtle sorter.
While some talk with Bess, the residue keep silence.
Though we play the knaves we must show a good pretence.
Where so ever some eat a serten keep the fruitier;
Where so ever some sleep some must needs keep the dorter.
Didst thou never know the manner of our senyes?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I was never with them acquainted, by Saint Denyes.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Then never knewest thou the knavery of our menyes.
if I should tell all I could say more than that.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Now, of good fellowship, I beseech thee show me what.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: The profitable lucre cometh ever in by me.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: But by what mean? Tell me, I heartily pray thee.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: to win the people I appoint each man his place:
Some to sing Latin, and some to duck at grace;
Some to go mumming, and some to bear the cross;
Some to stoop downward, as their heads were stopped with moss;
Some read the epistle and gospel at high mass;
Some sing at the lectern with long ears like an ass.
The pavement of the Church the ancient fathers treads,
Sometime with a portas, sometime with a pair of beads;
And this exceedingly draweth people to devotion,
Specially when they do see so good religion.
Then have we images of Saint Spryte and Saint Savyer:
Much is the seeking of them to get their favour;
Young women barefoot and old men seek them breech-less.
The miracles wrought there I can in nowise express.
we lack neither gold, nor silver girdles, nor rings,
Candles, nor tapers, nor other customed offerings.
Though I seem a sheep, I can play the subtle fox:
I can make Latin to bring this gear to the box.
Tush, Latin is alone to bring such matter to pass;
there is no English that can such profits compass.
And therefore we will no service to be sung,
Gospel nor Epistle, but all in Latin tongue.
Of our subtle drifts many more points are behind;
if I told you all, we should never have an end.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: In nomine Patris of all that ever I hard
Thou art alone yet of such a dreaming buzzard

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Nay, dost thou not see how I in my colours jet?
to blind the people I have yet a farther fette.
This is for Bernard, and this is for Benet,
This is for Gylbard, and this is for Jhenet;
for Frauncys this is, and this is for Domynyke,
for Awsten and Elen, and this is for Saint Partryk.
we have many rules, but never one we keep;
When we sing full loud our hearts be fast asleep.
we resemble saints in gray, white, black and blue,
Yet unto princes not one of our number true
And that shall king Johan prove shortly, by the rode.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: But in the mean time yourselves get little good;
your abbeys go down, I hear say every where.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Yea, friend Sedition, but thou must see to that gear.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Then must I have help, by sweet Saint Benettes cup.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Thou shalt have a child of mine own bringing up.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Of thy bringing up Cokes soul, what knave is that.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Marry, Private Wealth; now have I told thee what.
I made him a monk and a perfect cloisterer,
And in the abbey he became first cellarist,
Then prior, then abbot of a thousand pound land, no worse.
Now he is a bishop and rideth with an hundred horse,
And, as I hear say, he is like to be cardinal.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Is he so in deed? by the mass, then have at all

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Nay, first, Private Wealth shall bring in Usurped Power
With his authority, and then the game is over.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Tush, Usurped Power doth favour me of all men,
for in his troubles I ease his heart now and then.
I make their commons against them for to be.
Twenty thousand men are but a morning breakfast
to be slain for him, he taking his repast.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Thou hast, I perceive, a very subtle cast.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I am for the Pope as for the ship the mast.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Then help, Sedition, I may still in England be:
King Johan hath threatened that I shall over see.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Well, if thou wilt of me have remedy this hour,
Go fetch Private Wealth and also Usurped Power.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: I can bring but one be Marry, Jesus mother.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Bring thou in the one and let him bring in the other.

body.stage: Here cum in Usurpyd Powre and Private Welth, syngyng on after another.

l.foreign: Super flumina Babilonis suspendimus organa nostra.
Quomodo cantabimus canticum bonum in terra aliena.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: by the mass, methink they are singing of placebo

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Peace, for with my spectacles vadam et videbo
Cokes soul, it is they: at the last I have smelled them out .

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Thou mayst be a sow if thou hast so good a snout.
Sures, mark well this gear for now it beginneth to work:
False Dissimulation doth bring in Private Wealth;
And Usurped Power, which is more fierce than a Turk,
Cometh in by him to deceive all spiritual health;
Then I by them both, as clear experience telleth.
we four by our crafts King Johan will so subdue
that for three hundred years all England shall it rue.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Of the clergy, friends, report like as ye see,
that there Private Wealth cometh ever in by me.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: But by whom comest thou? by the mass, even by the devil,
for the ground thou art of the Christian people's evil.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: And what are you, sir? I pray you say good be me.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: by my troth, I come by thee and thy affinity.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Fetch thou in thy fellow so fast as ever thou can.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: I trow thou shalt see me now play the praty man.
Of me, Private Wealth, cam first Usurped Power:
Ye may perceive it in pageant here this hour.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Now welcome, fellows, by all these bones and nails

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Among companions good fellowship never fails.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Nay, Usurped Power, thou must go back again,
for I must also put thee to a little pain.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Why, fellow Sedition, what will thou have me do?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: to bare me on thy back and bring me in also
that it may be said that first Dissimulation
Brought in Private Wealth to every Christian nation,
And that Private Wealth brought in Usurped Power,
And he Sedition in city, town and tower
that some man may know the fetch of all our sort.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Come on thy ways, then, that thou mayst make thee for it.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Nay, Usurped Power, we shall bare him all three,
Thyself, he, and I, if ye will be ruled by me.
for there is none of us but in him hath a stroke.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: The whoreson knave weigheth and it were a croked oak

body.stage: Here they shall bare hym in, and Sedycyon saythe

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Yea, thus it should be. Marry, now I am aloft
I will beshite you all if ye set me not down soft.
in my opinion, by sweet Saint Antony,
Here is now gathered a full honest company.
Here is neither Awsten, Ambrose, Hierom nor Gregory,
But here is a sort of companions much more merry.
They of the Church then were four holy doctors,
we of the Church now are the four general proctors.
Here is first of all good father Dissimulation,
The first beginner of this same congregation;
Here is Private Wealth which hath the Church infect
With all abusing and brought it to a sinful sect;
Here is Usurped Power, that all kings doth subdue
With such authority as is neither good nor true:
And I last of all am even sance pere Sedition.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Under heaven is not a more knave in condition.
where as thou dost come that common Wealth cannot thrive.
by our Lord, I marvel that thou art yet alive

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: where herbs are plucked up the weeds many times remain.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: no man can utter an evidence more plain.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Yea, ye think so, you? Now Gods blessing break your head.
I can do but laugh to hear you, by this bread
I am so merry that we are met, by Saint John,
I feel not the ground that I do go upon.
for the love of God, let us have some merry song.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Begin thyself then, and we shall leap in among.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I would ever dwell here to have such merry sport.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Thou mayst have it, man, if thou wilt hither resort,
for the Holy Father is as good a fellow as we.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: The Holy Father Why, I pray thee, which is he?

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: UsurpedPower here, which though he apparent be
in this apparel, yet hath he authority
both in heaven and earth, in purgatory and in hell.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Mark well his sayings, for a true tale he doth tell.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: What, Usurped Power? Cock's soul, ye are our Pope?
Where is your three cronies, your cross keys, and your cope?
What meaneth this matter? Methink ye walk astray.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Thou knowest I must have some dalliance and play,
for I am a man like as an other is.
Sometime I must hunt, sometime I must Alison kiss.
I am bold of you, I take ye for no strangers.
we are as spiritual; I doubt in you no dangers.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: I ought to consider your Holy Fatherhood,
From my first infancy ye have been to me so good.
for Gods sake wytsave to give me your blessing here,

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: A pena et culpa that I may stand this day clear.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: From making cuckolds? Marry, that were no merry cheer.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: A pena et culpa I trow thou canst not here.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Yea, with a cuckolds wife ye have drunk double beer.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: I pray thee, Sedition, my patience no more stir;
A pena et culpa I desire to be clear,
And then all the devils of hell I would not fere.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: But tell me one thing: dost thou not preach the Gospel?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: no, I promise you, I defy it to the devil of hell

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: if I knew thou didst thou shouldst have non absolution.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: if I do, abjure me or put me to execution.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: I dare say he breaketh no popish constitution.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Such men are worthy to have our contribution:
I assoil thee here, behind and also before.
Now art thou as clear as that day thou wert born.
Rise, Dissimulation, and stand Up like a bold knight.
Doubt not of my power though my apparel be light.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: A man, be the mass, cannot know you from a knave;
Ye look so like him as I would God should me save.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Thou art very lewd our father so to deprave.
Though he for his pleasure such light apparel have,
it is now summer and the heat is without measure,
And among us he may go light at his own pleasure.
Fellow Sedition, though thou dost mock and scoff,
we have other matters than this to be commined of;
Friend Dissimulation, why dost thou not thy massage
And show out of England the cause of thy far passage?
Tush, blemish not, whoreson, for I shall ever assist thee.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: The knave is white liveried, by the Holy Trinity

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Why so, Private Wealth? What is the matter? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Dissimulation is a messenger for the clergy;
I must speak for him, there is no remedy.
The clergy of Ynglond, which is your special friend,
And of a long time hath borne you very good mind,
Filling your coffers with many a thousand pound,
if ye set not to hand he is like to fall to the ground.
I do promise you truly his heart is in his hose;
King Johan so useth him that he reckoneth all to lose.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Tell, Dissimulation, why art thou so ashamed
to show thy massage? Thou art much to be blamed.
Late me see those writings. Tush, man, I pray thee come near.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: your horrible holiness puteth me in wonderful fere.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Tush, let me see them, I pray thee heartily.

body.stage: Here Dissimulacyon shall delever the wrytynges to Usurpyd Powre.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: I perceive it well: thou wilt lose no ceremony.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Yet is he no less than a false knave, verily.
I would thou haddest kissed his arse for that is holy.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: How dost thou prove me that his arse is holy now?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: for it hath an hole even fit for the nose of you.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: your part is not else but for to play the knave,
And so ye must still continue to your grave.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: I say leave your gauds and attend to me this hour.
The bishops writeth here to me, Usurped Power,
Desiring assistance of mine authority
to save and support the Church's liberty.
They report King Johan to them to be very hard
And to have the Church in no price nor regard.
in his parliament he demandeth of the clergy
for his wars the tent of the Church's patrimony.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Ye will not consent to that, I trow, by Saint Marry

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: no, draw to you still, but let none from you carry.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Ye know it is clean against our holy decrees
that princes should thus condemn our liberties.
He taketh upon him to reform the tithes and offerings,
And intermedleth with other spiritual things.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Ye must sequester him or else that will mare all.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Nay, besides all this before judges temporal
He conventeth clerks of causes criminal.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: if ye see not to that, the Church will have a fall.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: by the mass, then priests are like to have a pang;
for treason, murder, and theft they are like to hang.
by cock's soul, then I am like to walk for treason
if I be taken. Look to it therefore in season.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Marry, God forbid that ever your holy anointed
for treason or theft should be hanged, racked or jointed
like the rascal sort of the profane layette.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Nay, I shall otherwise look to it, ye may trust me.
Before himself also the bishops he doth convent,
to the derogation of their dignity excellent,
And will suffer none to the court of Rome to appeal.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: no, he contemneth your authority and seal,
And saith in his land he will be lord and king,
no priest so hardy to enterprise anything.
for the which of late with him were at variance
Four of his bishops, and in manner at defiance:
Wyllyum of London, and Eustace, Bishop of Hely,
Water of Wynchester, and Gylys of Hartford, truly.
Be your authority they have him excommunicate.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Then have they done well, for he is a reprobate.
to that I admit he is always contrary.
I made this fellow here the Archbishop of Canterbury,
And he will agree thereto in no condition

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Then hath he knowledge that his name is Sedition?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Doubtless he hath so, and that drowneth his opinion.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Why do ye not say his name is Stevyn Langton?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Tush, we have done so, but that helpeth not the matter:
The Bishop of Norwych for that cause doth him flatter.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Stick thou to it fast, we have once admitted thee.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I will not one jot from my admission flee:
The best of them all shall know that I am he.
Nay, in such matters let men be ware of me.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: The monks of Caunterbey did more at my request
Than they would at his, concerning that election.
They chase Sedition as it is now manifest
in spite of his heart. Then he for their rebellion
Exiled them all, and toke their hole possession
Into his own hands, them sending over see
their livings to seek in extreme poverty.
This custom also he hath, as it is told me:
When prelates depart yea, bishop, abbot or curate
He entereth their lands without my liberty,
Taking the profits till the next be consecrate,
Institute, stallyd, induct, or intronyzate.
And of the pied monks he intendeth to take a dime.
All will be marred if I look not to it in time.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: it is taken, sir. The sum is unreasonable
A nine thousand mark: to live they are not able.
His suggestion was to subdue the Yrysh men.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Yea, that same people doth ease the Church now and then;
for that enterprise they would be looked upon.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: They get no money, but they shall have clean remission,
for those Yrysh men are ever good to the Church;
When kings disobey it then they begin to worship.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: And all that they do is for indulgence and pardon.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: by the mass, and that is not worth a rotten warden.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: What care we for that? to them it is venison.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Then let them have it, a Gods dear benison

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: Now, how shall we do for this same wicked king?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Suspend him and curse him both with your word and writing.
if that will not help, then interdict his land
With extreme cruelness; and if that will not stand
Cause other princes to revenge the church's wrong.
it will profit you to set them a-work among;
for clean remission one king will subdue another.
Yea, the child sometime will slay both father and mother.

sp.speaker: Usurpid Powre
sp.l: This counsel is good; I will now follow it plain.
Tarry thou still here till we return again.

body.stage: Here go owt Usurpid Powre and Privat Welth and Sedycyon.Usurpyd Powre shall drese for the Pope, Privat Welth for a Cardynall, and Sedycyon for a monke. The Cardynall shall bryng in the crose, and Stevyn Launton the bocke, bell and candell.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: This Usurped Power, which now is gone from hence,
for the Holy Church will make such ordinance
that all men shall be under his obedience.
Yea, kings will be glad to give him their allegiance,
And then shall we priests live here without disturbance.
As Gods own vicar anon ye shall see him sit,
His flock to advance by his most politic wit.
He shall make prelates, both bishop and cardinal
Doctors and prebends with furred hoods and side gowns.
He will also create the orders monastical,
Monks, canons and friars with gay coats and shaven crowns,
And build them places to corrupt cities and towns.
The dead saints shall show both visions and miracles
With images and relics he shall work sterracles.
He will make matins, hours, mass and evensong
to drown the scriptures for doubt of heresy;
He will send pardons to save men's souls among,
Latina devotions with the holy rosary.
He will appoint fastings and pluck down matrimony;
Holy water and bread shall drive away the devil;
Blessings with black beads will help in every evil.
King Johan of England because he hath rebelled
Against Holy Church using it worse than a stable,
to give up his crown shall shortly be compelled.
And the Albygeanes like heretics detestable,
Shall be brent because against our father they babble;
Through Dominic's preaching an eighteen thousand are slain
to teach them how they shall Holy Church disdain.
All this to perform he will call a general council
Of all Christendom to the church of Laternense.
His intent shall be for to suppress the Gospel,
Yet will he gloss it with a very good pretence:
to subdue the Turks by a Christian violence.
Under this colour he shall ground there many things,
Which will at the last be Christian men's undoings.
The Pope's power shall be above the powers all,
And hear confession a matter necessary.
Ceremonies will be the rights ecclesiastical.
He shall set up there both pardons and purgatory;
The Gospel preaching will be an heresy.
Be this provision, and be such other kinds
we shall be full sure all way to have our minds.

body.stage: Usurped Power returns as the Pope, Private Wealth as a Cardinal, and Sedition as Stephen Langton.

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: Ah, ye are a blab I perceive ye will tell all.
I left ye not here to be so liberal.

body.stage: Knele and knoke on thi bryst.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon

l.foreign: Mea culpa, mea culpa, gravissima mea culpa

sp.l: Give me your blessing pro Deo et sancta Maria

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: Thou hast my blessing. Arise now and stand aside.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: My skin is so thick it will not throw glide.

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: Let us go about our other matters now.
we wait her upon the great holiness of you.

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: for as much as King Johan doth Holy Church so handle,
Here I do curse him with cross, book, bell, and candle:
like as this same rood turneth now from me his face,
so God I require to sequester him of his grace;
As this book doth spear by my work manual,
I will God to close up from him his benefits all;
As this burning flame goeth from this candle in sight,
I will God to put him from his eternal light;
I take him from Christ, and after the sound of this bell
Both body and soul I give him to the devil of hell.
I take from him baptism with the other sacraments
And suffrages of the Church, both ember days and lents.
Here I take from him both penance and confession,
Mass of the five wounds, with censing and procession.
Here I take from him holy water and holy bread,
And never will them to stand him in any stead.
This thing to publish I constitute you three,
Giving you my power and my full authority.
With the grace of God we shall perform it then,

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: Then get you forward so fast as ever ye can
Upon a bon voyage. Yet let us sing merrily.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Then begin the song, and we shall follow gladly.

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: to colour this thing thou shalt be called Pandulphus;
Thou, Stevyn Langton; thy name shall be Raymundus.
First thou, Pandolphus, shalt openly him suspend
With book, bell and candle. if he will not so amend
Interdict his land and the churches all up spear.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: I have my massage: to do it I will not fear.

body.stage: Here go owt and dresse for Nobylyte.

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: And thou, Stevyn Langton, command the bishops all
so many to curse as are to him beneficial,
Dukes, earls and lords, whereby they may forsake him.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Sir, I will do it, and that, I trow, shall shake him.

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: Raymundus, go thou forth to the Christian princes all;
Bid them, in my name, that they uponhim fall,
both with fire and sword, that the Church may him conquer.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: your pleasure I will no longer time defer.

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: say this to them also: Pope Innocent the Thread
Remission of sins to so many men hath granted
As will do their best to slay him if they may.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Sir, it shall be done without any longer delay.

sp.speaker: The Pope
sp.l: in the mean season I shall such gear advance
As will be to us a perpetual furtherance:
First hear confession, then pardons, then purgatory,
Saints worshipping then, then seeking of imagery,
Then Latin service with the ceremonies many
Whereby our bishops and abbots shall get money.
I will make a law to burn all heretics,
And kings to depose when they are schismatics.
I will also raise up the four begging orders
that they may preach lies in all the Christian borders.
for this and other I will call a general council
to ratify them in like strength with the Gospel.

body.stage: Here the Pope go owt Enter the Interpreter.

sp.l: in this present act we have to you declared
As in a mirror the beginning of King Johan,
How he was of God a magistrate appointed
to the governance of this same noble region,
to see maintained the true faith and religion.
But Satan the Devil, which that time was at large,
Had so great a swaye that he could it not discharge.
upon a good zeal he attempted very far
for wealth of this realm to provide reformation
in the Church thereof, but they did him debar
Of that good purpose; for by excommunication
The space of seven years they interdict thy nation.
These bloodsuppers thus of cruelty and spite
Subdued this good king for executing right.
in the second act this will appear more plain
Wherein Pandulphus shall him excommunicate
Within this his land, and depose him from his reign.
All other princes they shall move him to hate
And to persecute after most cruel rate.
They will him poison in their malignity
And cause ill report of him always to be.
this noble king Johan as a faithful Moses
Withstood proud Pharao for his poor Israel,
Minding to bring it out of the land of darkness.
But the Egyptians did against him so rebel
that his poor people did still in the desert dwell,
Till that duke Josue which was our late king Henry
Clearly brought us in to the land of milk and honey.
As a strong David at the voice of verity
Great Golye, the Pope, he strake down with his sling
Restoring again to a Christen liberty
his land and people, like a most victorious king,
to her first beauty intending the church to bring
From ceremonies dead to the living word of the Lord,
this the second act will plenteously record.

body.stage: Sedition and Nobylyte cum in and say:

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: It pitieth my heart to see the controversy
that now a days reigneth between the king and the clergy.
All Canterbury monks are now the realm exiled,
The priests and bishops continually reviled
The Cistercian monks are in such perplexity
that out of England they reckon all to flee.
I lament the chance as I would God should me save.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: it is graciously said: Gods blessing might ye have
Blessed is that man that will grant or condescend
to help religion or Holy Church defend.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: for their maintenance I have given lands full fair
And have disherited many a lawful heir.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Well, it is your own good; God shall reward you for it,
And in heaven full high for such good works shall ye sit.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: your habit showeth ye to be a man of religion.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I am no worse, sir; my name is Good Perfection.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I am the more glad to be acquainted with ye.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Ye show yourself here like a noble man as ye be.
I perceive right well your name is Nobility.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: your servant and umfrey. Of truth, father, I am he.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: From Innocent the Pope I am come from Rome even now.
A thousand times, I wean, he commendeth him unto you
And sent you clean remission to take the Church's part.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I thank his holiness. I shall do it with my heart.
if ye would take pains for hearing my confession,
I would out of hand receive this clean remission.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Marry, with all my heart, I will be full glad to do it.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Put on your stole, then, and I pray you in Gods name sit.

body.stage: Here sett down and Nobelyte shall say Benedycyte.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: benedicte.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Dominus: In nomine domini pape, amen Say forth your mind in Gods name.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I have sinned against God; I knowledge myself to blame.
in the seven deadly sins I have offended sore;
Gods ten commandments I have broken ever more;
My five bodily wits I have ungodly kept;
The works of charity in manner I have outslept.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I trust ye believe as Holy Church doth teach ye?
And from the new learning ye are willing for to flee?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: From the new learning? Marry, God of heaven save me
I never loved it of a child, so mote I thee.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Ye can say your creed? And your Latin Ave Marry?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Yea, and dirge also, with seven psalms and litany.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Do ye not believe in purgatory and holy bred?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Yes, and that good prayers shall stand my soul in stead.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Well, than, good enough; I warrant my sole for your.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Then execute on me the holy father's power.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Nay, while I have you here underneath benedicte
in the Popes behalf I must move other things to ye.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: in the name of God say here what ye will to me.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Ye know that King Johan is a very wicked man
And to Holy Church a continual adversary.
The Pope willeth you to do the best ye can
to his subduing for his cruel tyranny;
And for that purpose this privilege graciously
Of clean remission he hath sent you this time
Clean to release you of all your sin and crime.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: it is clean against the nature of Nobility
to subdue his king without Gods authority,
for his princely estate and power is of God.
I would gladly do it but I fere his rightful rode.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Gods holy vicar gave me his whole authority.
Lo, it is here, man, believe it, I beseech thee,
Or else thou wilt fall in danger of damnation.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Then I submit me to the Church's reformation.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I assoil thee here from the kings obedience
by the authority of the Pope's magnificence:

l.foreign: Auctoritate romani pontyficis ego absolvo te

sp.l: From all possessions given to the spirituality,
In nomine domini pape,amen.
Keep all things secret, I pray you heartily.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Yes, that I will, sir, and come again hither shortly.

body.stage: Here enter Clargy and Cyvyll Order together; and Sedysyon shall go up and down a praty whyle.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Is not your fatherhood Archbishop of Canterbury?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I am Stevyn Langton. Why make ye here inquiry?
Ye are right welcome to this same region, truly.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Stand up, I pray you. I trow thou art the Clergy,

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I am the same, sir, and this is Civil Order.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: if a man might axe you what make you in this border?

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I herd tell yester day ye were come in to the land
I thought for to see you, some, news to understand.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: in faith, thou art welcome. Is Civil Order thy friend?

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: He is a good man and beareth the church good mind.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Right sorry I am of the great controversy
Between him and the king, if I might it remedy.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Well, Civil Order, for thy good will gramercy;
that matter will be of an other fashion shortly.
First, to begin with we shall interdict the land.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Marry, God forbid we should be in such band
But who shall do it, I pray you heartily?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Pandulphus and I; we have it in our legacy.
He went to the king for that cause yester day,
And I will follow so fast as ever I may.
Lo, here is the bull of mine authority.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I pray God to save the Popes holy majesty.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Sit down on your knees and ye shall have absolution
A pena et culpa with a thousand days of pardon.
Here is first a bone of the blessed Trinity,
A dram of the turd of sweet Saint Barnaby;
Here is a feather of good Saint Michael's wing,
A tooth of Saint Twyde, a piece of David's harp string,
The good blood of Haylys, and our blessed lady's milk,
A louse of Saint Fraunces in this same crimson silk,
A scab of Saint Job, a nail of Adams too,
A maggot of Moses, with a fart of Saint Fandigo;
Here is a fig leaf, and a grape of Noes vineyard,
A bead of Saint Blythe with the bracelet of a bearward,
The Devil that was hatched in master Johan Shornes boat,
that the tree of Jesse did pluck up by the root;
Here is the lachet of sweet Saint Thomas show,
A rib of Saint Rabart with the huckle bone of a Jew;
Here is a joint of Darvell Gathyron,
Besides other bones and relics many one.
In nomine domini pape, amen.
Arise now like men and stand uponyour fete,
for here ye have caught an holy and a blessed heat.
Ye are now as clean as that day ye were born,
And like to have increase of children, cattle and corn.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Children? He can have none, for he is not of that load.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Tush, though he hath none at home, he may have some abroad.
Now Clergy, my friend, this must thou do for the Pope
And for Holy Church; thou must men's conscience grope,
And as thou feelest them so cause them for to work.
Let them show King Johan no more favour than a Turk.
Everywhere stir them to make an insurrection.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: All that shall I do and to provoke them more,
This interdiction I will lament very sore
in all my preachings, and say through his occasion
All we are under the danger of damnation;
And this will move people to help to put him down,
Or else compel him to give up sceptre and crown.
Yea, and that will make those kings that shall succeed
Of the Holy Church to stand ever more in dread.
And besides all this the church doors I will upseal,
And close up the bells that they ring never a peal.
I will spere up the chalice, crysmatory, cross and all,
that mass they shall have none, baptism nor burial.
And this I know well will make the people mad.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Marry, that it will; such; sauce he never had.
And what wilt thou do for Holy Church, Civil Order?

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: for the clergy's sake, I will in every border
Provoke the great men to take the commons's part.
With cautelous of the law I will so tickle their heart
They shall think all good that they shall pass upon,
And so shall we come to our full intent anon;
for if the Church thrive then do we lawyers thrive,
And if they decay our wealth is not alive.
Therefore we must help your state, masters, to uphold,
Or else our profits will cache a winter cold.
I never knew lawyer which had any crafty learning
that ever escaped you without a plenteous living;
Therefore we may not leave Holy Church's quarrel,
But ever help it, for their fall is our apparel.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Gods blessing have ye This gear then will work I trust.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Or else some of us are like to lie in the dust.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Let us all avoid Be the mass, the king cometh here

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I would hyde myself for a time if I wist where.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Go we hence apace, for I have spied a corner.

body.stage: Here go owt all, and Kyng Johan cummyth in.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: for none other cause God hath kings constitute
And given them the sword but for to correct all vice.
I have attempted this thing to execute
Upon transgressors according unto justice,
And because I will not be partial in mine office
for theft and murder to persons spiritual,
I have against me the priests and the bishops all.
Alike displeasure in my father's time did fall
Forty years ago for punishment of a clarke.
no counsel might them to reformation call,
in their opinion they were so sturdy and stark,
But against their prince to the Pope they did so bark
that here in Ynglond, in every city and town
Excommunications as thunder bolts cam down.
for this their captain had after a pared crown
And died upon it without, the kings consent.
Then interdictions were sent from the Popes renown,
Which never left him till he was penitent
And fully agreed unto the Popes appointment,
in Ynglond to stand with the Church's liberty,
And suffer the priests to Rome for appeals to flee.
They bound him also to help Jerusalem city
With two hundred men the space of a year and more,
And three year after to maintain battle free
Against the Saracens which vexed the Spaniards sore.
Since my father's time I have borne them grog therefore,
Considering the pride and the capacious disdain
that they have to kings which ought over them to reign.

body.stage: Privat Welth cum in lyke a cardynall.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: God save you, sir king, in your princely majesty.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Friend, ye be welcome. What is your pleasure with me?

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: From the holy father, Pope Innocent the Thread,
As a messenger I am to you directed
to reform the peace between Holy Church and you.
And in his behalf I advertise you here now
Of the Church's goods to make full restitution,
And to accept also the Pope's holy constitution
for Stevyn Langton, Archbishop of Canterbury,
And so admit him to his state and primacy.
The monks exiled ye shall restore again
to their places and lands and nothing of theirs retain.
Our holy father's mind is that ye shall again restore
All that ye have ravished from Holy Church with the more.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I reckon your father will never be so hard
But he will my cause as well as theirs regard.
I have done nothing but that I may do well
And as for their tax I have for me the Gospel.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Tush, Gospel or no ye must make a recompense.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: your father is sharpe and very quick in sentence
if he weigheth the word of God no more than so.
But I shall tell you in this what I shall do:
I am well content to receive the monks again
upon amendment; but as for Stevyn Langton, plain,
He shall not come here, for I know his disposition.
He is much inclined to sturdiness and sedition.
there shall no man rule in the land where I am king
Without my consent for no man's pleasure living.
Never the less yet upon a new behaver,
At the Pope's request hereafter I may him favour
And grant him to have some other benefice.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: by this I perceive ye bare him grog and malice.
Well, this will I say, because ye are so blunt:
