A prelate to discharge Holy Church was never wont,
But her custom is to minister punishment
to kings and princes being disobedient.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Avaunt, peevish priest What, dost thou threaten me?
I defy the worst both of thy Pope and thee.
The power of princes is given from God above,
And, as saith Solomon, their hearts the Lord doth move.
God speaketh in their lips when they give judgment.
The laws that they make are by the Lords appointment.
Christ willed not his the princes to correct
But to their precepts rather to be subject.
The office of you is not to bear the sword,
But to give counsel according to Gods word.
He never taught his to wear neither sword nor sallet
But to preach abroad without staff, scrip or wallet;
Yet are ye become such mighty lords this hour
that ye are able to subdue all princes power.
I cannot perceive but ye are become Bells priests,
Living by idols; yea, the very antichrists.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Ye have said your mind, now will I say mine also.
Here I curse you for the wrongs that ye have do
Unto Holy Church, with cross, book, bell and candle;
And besides all this I must you otherwise handle.
Of contumacy the Pope hath you convicted;
From this day forward your land stand interdict.
The Bishop of Norwyche and the Bishop of Wynchester
Hath full authority to spread it in Ynglond here;
The Bishop of Salysbery and the Bishop of Rochester
Shall execute it in Scotlond everywhere;
The Bishop of Landaffe, Saint Assys and Saint Davy
in Walles and in Ireland shall publish it openly.
Throughout all Christendom the bishops shall suspend
All such as to you any maintenance pretend;
And I curse all them that give to you their heart,
Dukes, earls and lords, so many as take your part;
And I assoil your people from your obedience,
that they shall owe you neither fealty nor reverence.
by the Pope's authority I charge them with you to fight
As with a tyrant against Holy Churches right;
And by the Pope's authority I give them absolution
A pena et culpa and also clean remission.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Alarum Alarum Tro ro ro ro ro, tro ro ro ro ro, tro ro ro ro ro
Thomp, thomp, thomp down, down, down, to go, to go, to go

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: What a noise is this that without the door is made?

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Such enemies are up as will your realm invade.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Ye could no nomor and ye cam from the devil of hell
Then ye go about here to work by your wicked counsel.
Is this the charity of that ye call the Church?
God grant Christian men not after your ways to worship.
I set not by your curses the shaking of a rod,
for I know they are of the devil and not of God.
your curses we have that we never yet demanded,
But we cannot have that God hath you commanded.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: What ye mean by that I would ye should openly tell.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Why, know ye it not? The preaching of the Gospel.
Take to ye your trash, your ringing, singing and piping,
so that we may have the scriptures opening.
But that we cannot have: it standeth not with your advantage.

sp.speaker: Privat Welth
sp.l: Ah Now I fell you for this heretical language:
I think neither you nor any of yours, iwis,
we will so provide, shall wear the crown after this.

body.stage: Go owt and dresse for Nobylyte.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: it become not the Gods secret works to deem.
Get thee hence, or else we shall teach thee to blaspheme
o Lord, how wicked is that same generation
that never will come to a godly reformation.
The priests report me to be a wicked tyrant
Because I correct their acts and life unpleasant.
Of thy prince, saith God, thou shalt report non ill,
But thyself apply his pleasure to fulfil.
The birds of the air shall speak to their great shame,
As saith Ecclesiastes, that will a prince defame.
The powers are of God, I wot Powle hath such sentence;
He that resist them against God maketh resistance.
Marry and Joseph, at Cyrinus appointment
in the description to Caesar were obedient.
Christ did pay tribute for himself and Peter too,
for a law prescribing the same unto priests also;
to profane princes he obeyed unto death.
so did Johan Baptist so long as he had breath.
Peter, Johan and Powle, with the other apostles all
Did never withstand the powers imperial.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Priests are so wicked they will obey no power,
But seek to subdue their princes day and hour,
As they would do me: but I shall make them smart
if that nobility and law will take my part.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Doubtless we cannot till ye be reconciled
Unto Holy Church, for ye are a man defiled.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: How am I defiled? tell me, good gentle mate.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: by the Popes high power ye are excommunicate.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: by the word of God, I pray thee, what power hath he?

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: I spake not with him, and therefore I cannot tell ye.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: With whom spake ye not? Let me know your intent.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Marry, not with God since the latter week of Lent.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: o merciful God, what an unwise clause is this
Of him that should see that nothing were amiss.
that sentence or curse that scripture doth not direct
in my opinion shall be of no effect.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Is that your believe? Marry God save me from you

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Prove it by scripture and then will I it allow.
But this know I well: when Baalam gave the curse
Upon Gods people they were never a whit the worse.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I pass not on the scripture: that is enough for me
Which the Holy Father approveth by his authority.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Now alas, alas What wretched people ye are
And how ignorant your own words doth declare.
Woo is that people which hath so wicked teachers.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Nay, woe is that people that hath so cruel rulers.
Our Holy Father, I trow, could do no less,
Considering the facts of your outrageousness.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Come away, for shame, and make no more ado.
Ye are in great danger for communing with him so.
He is accursed; I marvel ye do not weigh it.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I hear by his words that he will not obey it.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Whether he will or no, I will not with him talk
Till he be assoiled. Come on, my friends, will ye walk?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: o, this is no token of true nobility
to flee from your king in his extremity.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I shall desire you as now to pardon me;
I had much rather do against God, verily,
Then to Holy Church to do any injury.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: What blindness is this? on this people, lord, have mercy
Ye speak of defiling, but ye are corrupted all
With pestilent doctrine or leaven pharisaical.
Good and faithful Susan said that it was much better
to fall in danger of men than do the greater,
As to leave Gods law which is his word most pure.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Ye have nothing, you, to allege to us but scripture?
Ye shall fare the worse for that, ye may be sure.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: What should I allege else, thou wicked Pharisee?
to your false learning no faithful man will agree.
Doth not the Lord say nunc reges intelligite
The kings of the earth that worldly causes judge,
Seek to the scripture, let that be your refuge?

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Have ye nothing else but this? Then God be with ye

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: One question more yet ere ye depart from me
I will first demand of you, Nobility:
Why leave ye your prince and cleave to the Pope so sore?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: for I toke an oath to defend the Church ever more.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Clergy, I am sure than your quarrel is not small.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I am professed to the rights ecclesiastical.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: And you, Civil Order, oweth her some office of duty?

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: I am her feed man; who should defend her but I?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Of all three parties it is spoken reasonably:
Ye may not obey because of the oath ye mad,
your strong profession maketh you of that same trade,
your fee provoketh you to do as these men do.
Great things to cause men from God to the devil to go
your oath is grounded first upon foolishness,
And your profession upon much peevishness;
your fee, last of all, riseth out of covetousness,
And these are the causes of your rebelliousness.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Come, Civil Order, let us too depart from hence.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then are ye at a point for your obedience?

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: we will in no wis be partakers of your ill.

body.stage: Here go owt Clargy and dresse for Ynglond, and Syvyll Order for Commynnalte.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: As ye have been ever so ye will continue still.
Though they be gone, tarry you with me a while;
The presence of a prince to you should never be vile.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Sir, nothing grieveth me but your excommunication.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: that is but a fantasy in your imagination.
The Lord refuse not such as hath his great curse,
But call them to grace and favour them never the worse.
Saint Pawle willeth you when ye are among such sort
Not to abhor them but give them words of comfort.
Why should ye then flee from me, your lawful king,
for pleasure of such as ought to do no such thing?
The Church's abusing, as holy Saint Powle do say,
by the princes power ought for to be taken away;
He beareth not the sword without a cause, saith he.
in this neither bishop nor spiritual man is free;
Offending the law, they are under the powers all.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: How will ye prove me that the father's spiritual
Were under the princes ever continually?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: by the acts of kings I will prove it by and by:
David and Solomon the priests did constitute,
Commanding the offices that they should execute.
Josaphat the king the ministers did appoint;
so did King Ezechias whom God himself did anoint.
Diverse of the princes for the priests did make decrees,
like as it is plain in the first of Machabees.
Our priests are risen through liberty of kings
by riches to pride and other unlawful doings
And that is the cause that they so oft disobey.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Good Lord, what a craft have you these things to convey

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Now, alas, that the false pretence of superstition
should cause you to be a maintainer of sedition
Some thinketh nobility in nature to consist,
Or in parentage; their thought is but a mist.
where abundance is of virtue, faith and grace,
With knowledge of the Lord nobility is there in place,
And not where as is the wilful contempt of things
Pertaining to God in the obedience of kings.
Beware ye sink not with Dathan and Abiron
for disobeying the power and dominion.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Nay, bid me be ware I do not sink with you here;
Being accursed, of truth ye put me in fere.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Why, are ye gone hence? And will ye no longer tarry?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: no, where as you are in place, by sweet saint Mary

body.stage: Here Nobelyte go owt and dresse for the Cardynall. Here enter Ynglond and Commynalte.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Blessed lord of heaven, what is the wretchedness
Of this wicked world? An evil of all evils doubtless.
Perceive ye not here how the clergy hath reject
Their true allegiance to maintain the popish sect?
See ye not how light the lawyers set the poor
whom God commandeth them to obey each day and hour?
Nobility also which ought his prince to assist
Is vanished away as it were a winter mist.
All they are from me; I am now left alone,
And, God wot, know not to whom to make my moan.
o, yet would I fain know the mind of my Commonalty,
Whether he will go with them or abide with me.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: He is here at hand, a simple creature as may be.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Come hither, my friend, stand near. Is thyself he?

sp.speaker: Commynnalte
sp.l: if it like your grace, I am your pore Commonalty.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Thou art poor enough; if that be good, God help thee
Methink thou art blind. Tell me, friend, canst thou not see?

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: He is blind in deed, it is the more rueth and pity.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: How comest thou so blind? I pray thee, good fellow, tell me.

sp.speaker: Commynnalte
sp.l: for want of knowledge in Christ's lively verity.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: This spiritual blindness bringeth men out of the way,
And cause them oft times their kings to disobey.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: How sayst thou, Commonalty? Wilt not thou take my part?

sp.speaker: Commynnalte
sp.l: to that I could be contented with all my heart,
But alas, in me are two great impediments.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I pray thee, show me what are those impediments.

sp.speaker: Commynnalte
sp.l: The first is blindness, whereby I might take with the Pope
Sooner than with you; for, alas, I can but grope,
And ye know full well there are many naughty guides.
The next is poverty, which cleave so hard to my sides
And punish me so sore that my power is little or none.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: in Gods name, tell me how cometh thy substance gone?

sp.speaker: Commynnalte
sp.l: by priests, cannons and monks, which do but fill their belly
With my sweat and labour for their popish purgatory.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: your grace promised me that I should have remedy
in that same matter when I was last here truly.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Doubtless I did so; but, alas, it will not be.
in heart I lament this great infelicity.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Let me have my spouse and my lands at liberty,
And I promise you my son here, your Commonality
I will make able to do ye dutiful service.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I would I were able to do to thee that office,
But, alas, I am not for why my nobility,
My lawyers and clergy hath cowardly forsake me;
And now last of all, to my most anguish of mind,
My Commonalty here I find both poor and blind.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Rest upon this, sir, for my governor ye shall be
so long as ye live; God hath so appointed me.
His outward blindness is but a signification
Of blindness in soul for lack of information
in the word of God, which is the original ground
Of disobedience which all realms doth confound.
if your grace would cause Gods word to be taught sincerely
And subdue those priests that will not preach it truly,
The people should know to their prince their lawful duty;
But if ye permit continuance of hypocrisy
in monks canons and priests, and ministers of the clergy
your realm shall never be without much traitory.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: All that I perceive, and therefore I keep out friars
Lest they should bring thee much farther into the briars.
They have mad labour to inhabit this same region;
They shall for my time not enter my dominion.
we have too many of such vain lowghtes already.
I beshrew their hearts, they have made you two full needy.

body.stage: Here enter Pandwlfus the cardynall and sayth:

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: What, Commonalty, is this the covenant keeping?
Thou toldest me thou wouldst take him no more for thy king.

sp.speaker: Commynnalte
sp.l: Peccavi, mea culpa I submit me to your holiness.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Get thee hence then shortly and go about thy business
Wait on thy captains, Nobility and the Clergy,
With Civil Order, and the other company.
Blow out your trumpets, and set forth manfully:
The french king Phelype by sea doth hither apply
With the power of France to subdue this heretic.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I defy both him and thee, lewd schismatics
Why wilt thou forsake thy prince or thy prince leave thee?

sp.speaker: Commynnalte
sp.l: I must needs obey when Holy Church commandeth me.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: if thou leave thy king take me never for thy mother.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Tush, care not thou for that, I shall provide thee another.
it were fitter for you to be in another place.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: it shall become me to wait upon his grace
And do him service where as he is resident,
for I was given him of the Lord omnipotent.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Thou mayst not abide here, for why we have him caressed.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: I beshrew your hearts so have ye me unpursed.
if he be accursed then are we a mete couple,
for I am interdict: no salve that sore can supply.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: I say get thee hence and make me no more prating.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: I will not away from mine own lawful king,
Appointed of God till death shall us depart.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Will ye not in deed? Well then ye are like to smart.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: I smart all ready through your most subtle practice,
And am clean undone by your false merchandise,
your pardons, your bulls, your purgatory pickpurse,
your lent fasts, your schrifts, that I pray God give you his curse

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Thou shalt smart better or we have done with thee,
for we have this hour great navies upon the see
in every quarter, with this lollard here to fight
And to conquer him for the Holy Church's right.
we have in the north Alexander, the King of Scots,
With an army of men that for their towns cast lots;
on the south side we have the French king with his power,
which will slay and burn till he come to London tower;
in the west parts we have King Alphonse with the Spaniards
With ships full of gunpowder now coming hither towards;
And on the east side we have Esterlynges, Danes, and Norwayes
With such power landing as can be resisted noways.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: All that is not true that you have here expressed.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: by the mass, so true as I have now confessed.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: And what do ye mean by such an hurly burly?

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: for the Churches right to subdue ye manfully.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: to all that will fight I proclaim a Jubilee
Of clean remission, this tyrant here to slay.
Destroy his people, burn up both city and town,
that the Pope of Rome may have his sceptre and crown.
in the Churches cause to die this day be bold;
Your souls shall to heaven ere your flesh and bones be cold.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Most merciful God, as my trust is in thee,
so comfort me now in this extremity
As thou helpest David in his most heaviness
so help me this hour of thy grace, mercy, and goodness.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: This outward remorse that ye show here evident
Is a great likelihood and token of amendment.
How say ye, King Johan? Can ye find now in your heart
to obey Holy Church and give over your froward part?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Were it so possible to hold these enemies back,
that my sweet Ynglond perish not in this shipwreck?

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Possible, quoth he? Yea, they should go back indeed,
And their great armies to some other quarters lead,
Or else they have not so many good blessings now,
But as many cursings they shall have, I make God avow.
I promise you, sir, ye shall have special favour
if ye will submit yourself to Holy Church here.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I trust then ye will grant some deliberation
to have an answer of this your protestation.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Tush, give up the crown and make no more ado.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Your spiritual charity will be better to me than so.
The crown of a realm is a matter of great weight;
in giving it up we may not be too slight.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I say give it up Let us have no more ado.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Yea, and in our wars we will no farther go.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Ye will give me leave to talk first with my clergy?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: With them ye need not; they are at a point already.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then with my lawyers to hear what they will tell.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Ye shall ever have them as the clergy give them counsel.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then will I come with my Nobility.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: we have him so juggled he will not to you agree.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Yet shall I be content to do as he counsel me.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Then be not too long from hence, I will advise ye.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Is not this a sport? by the mass, it is, I trow.
What wealth and pleasure will now to our kingdom grow
England is our own, which is the most pleasant ground
in all the round world Now may we realms confound.
our Holy Father may now live at his pleasure,
And have abundance of wenches, wines and treasure.
He is now able to keep down Christ and his gospel,
True faith to exile, and all vertues to expel.
Now shall we ruffle it in velvets, gold and silk,
With shaven crowns, side gowns, and rochettes white as milk.
by the mass, Pandulphus, now may we sing Cantata,
And crow Confiteor with a joyful Jubilate
Hold me, or else for laughing I must burst

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Hold thy peace, whoreson, I wean thou art accursed.
Keep a sad countenance. A very vengeance take thee

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I cannot do it, by the mass, if thou shouldst hang me.
If Solon were here, I reckon that he would laugh,
Which never laughed yet; yea, like a whelp he would waugh.
ha, ha, ha
Laugh, quoth he Yea, laugh and laugh again
we had never cause to laugh more free, I am plain.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: I pray thee no more, for here come the king again.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Ye are at a point whereto ye intend to stand?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Yea, hardly sir: give up the crown of England.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I have cast in mind the great displeasures of war,
The dangers, the losses, the decays both near and far,
The burning of towns, the throwing down of buildings,
Destruction of corn and cattle, with other things,
Defiling of maids, and shedding of Christen blood,
With such like outrages, neither honest, true nor good.
These things considered, I am compelled this hour
to resign up here both crown and regal power.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: for the love of God, yet take some better advisement.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Hold your tongue, ye whore, or by the mass ye shall repent
down on your marry bones, and make no more ado.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: If ye love me, sir, for Gods sake do never so.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: O England, England, show now thyself a mother;
Thy people will else be slain here without number.
As God shall judge me I do not this of cowardness,
But of compassion in this extreme heaviness.
Shall my people shed their blood in such abundance?
Nay, I shall rather give up my whole governance.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Come of apace, then, and make an end of it shortly.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: The most pitiful chance that hath been hitherto, surely.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Here I submit me to Pope Innocent the Thread,
Desiring mercy of his holy fatherhood.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Give up the crown, then; it shall be the better for ye.
He will unto you the more favourable be.

body.stage: Here the Kyng delevyr the crowne to the Cardynall.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: to him I resign here the sceptre and the crown
Of Ynglond and Yrelond, with the power and renown,
And put me wholly to his merciful ordinance.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: I may say this day the Church hath a full great chance.
These five days I will keep this crown in mine own hand,
in the Popes behalf upseizing Ynglond and Yerlond.
in the mean season ye shall make an obligation
for you and your heirs in this signification:
to receive your crown of the Pope for evermore
in manner of fee-farm; and for a token therefore
Ye shall every year pay him a thousand mark
With the peter pens, and not against it bark.
Ye shall also give to the Bishop of Canterbury
A three thousand mark for his great injury.
to the Church besides for the great scathe ye have done
Forty thousand mark ye shall deliver soon.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Sir, the tax that I had of the hole realm of Ynglond
Amounted to no more but unto thirty thousand.
Why should I then pay so much unto the Clergy?

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Ye shall give it them; there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Shall they pay no tribute if the realm stand in rearage?

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Sir, they shall pay none; we will have no such bondage.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: The Pope had at once three hundred thousand mark.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: What is that to you? Ah, still ye will be stark.
Ye shall pay it, sir, there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: it shall be performed as ye will have it, truly.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: so noble a realm to stand tributary, alas,
to the Devils vicar Such fortune never was.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Out with this harlot Cock's soul, she hath let a fart
like a wretch thou liest; thy report is like as thou art.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Ye shall suffer the monks and cannons to make reentry
in to there abbeys, and to dwell there peaceably.
Ye shall see also to my great labour and charge
for other things else, we shall come more at large.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Sir, in every point I shall fulfil your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Then ply it apace, and let us have the treasure.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Alack for pity that ever ye granted this.
for me pore Ynglond ye have done sore amiss;
Of a free woman ye have now mad a bond maid.
yourself and heirs ye have forever decayed.
Alas, I had rather be underneath the Turk
Then under the wings of such a thief to lurk.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Content thee, Ynglond, for there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: if you be pleased then, I must consent gladly.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: If I should not grant here would be a wonderful spoil;
Every where the enemies would ruffle and turmoil.
The loss of people sticketh most unto my heart.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Do as ye think best; each way is to my smart.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Are ye at a point with the same obligation?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: it is here ready at your interrogation.

body.stage: Here Kyng John shall delevyr the oblygacyon.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: where is the money for your full restitution?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Here, sir, according to your last constitution.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Come hither, my lord. by the Pope's authority
Assoil this man here of irregularity.

body.stage: Here the bysshop Stevyn Langton cum in.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Methink this bishop resembleth much Sedition.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: I counsel you yet to be ware of wrong suspicion.
This is Stevyn Langton, yowre metropolitan.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then do the office of the good Samaritan,
And pore oil and wine in my old festered wound.
Release me of sin that it doth not me confound.

p.foreign: Confiteor Domino Pape et omnibus cardinalibus eius et vobis, quia peccavi nimis exigendo ab ecclesia tributum,mea culpa. Ideo precor sanctissimum Dominum Papam et omnes prelatos eius et vos,orare pro me.
Misereatur tui omnipotens Papa,et dimittat tibi omnes erratus tuos, liberetque te a suspencione excominicacione et interdicto,et restituat te in regnum tuum.

sp.speaker: K.Johan.
sp.l: Amen.

p.foreign: Dominus Papa noster te absolvat,et ego absolvo te auctoritate eius,et apostolorum Petri et Pauli in hac parte mihi comissa,ab omnibus impietatibus tuis,et restituo te corone et regno,in nomine Domini Pape. Amen.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Ye are well content to take this man for your primate?

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Yea, and to use him according to his estate.
I am right sorry that ever I you offended.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: And I am full glad that ye are so well amended.
Unto Holy Church ye are now an obedient child,
Where ye were afore with heresy much defiled.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Sir, yonder is a clarke which is condemned for treason,
The shrives would fain know what to do with him this season.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Come hither, fellow. What? Methink thou art a priest.

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: He hath ofter guessed that of the truth have missed.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: A priest and a traitor? How may that well agree?

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: Yes, yes, well enough, underneath benedicte
Myself hath played it, and therefore I know it the better.
Among crafty cloyners there hath not been a greater.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Tell some of thy feats; thou mayest the better escape.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Hem Not too bold yet for a mouse the cat will gape.

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: Twenty thousand traitor I have made in my time
Under benedicte between high mass and prime.
I made Nobility to be obedient
to the Church of Rome, which most kings may repent.
I have so conveyed that neither priest nor lawyer
Will obey Gods word, nor yet the Gospel favour.
in the place of Christ I have set up superstitions;
for preachings, ceremonies, for Gods word, men's traditions.
Come to the temple and there Christ hath no place;
Moyses and the pagans doth utterly him deface.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Mark well, sir. Tell what we have of Moyses.

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: All your ceremonies, your copes and your censers, doubtless,
Your fires, your waters, your oils, your altars, your ashes,
Your candlesticks, your cruets, your salt, with such like trashes;
Ye lack but the blood of a goat or else a calf.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Let us hear somewhat also in the pagans behalf.

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: Of the pagans ye have your gilded images all,
in your necessities upon them for to call
With crouchings, with kissings, and setting up of lights,
Bearing them in procession and fastings upon their nights;
Some for the tooth ache, some for the pestilence and pox,
With images of wax to bring money to the box.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: What have they of Christ in the Church? I pray thee tell.

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: Marry nothing at all but the Epistle and the Gospel,
And that is in Latina that no man should it know.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Peace, naughty whoreson, peace; thou playest the knave, I trow.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: hast thou known such ways, and sought no reformation?

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: It is the living of our whole congregation.
If superstitions and ceremonies from us fall,
Farewell monk and canon, priest, fryer, bishop and all.
our conveyance is such that we have both money and ware.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: our occupation thou wilt mar God give the care.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Very few of ye will Peters office take?

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: Yes, the more part of us our master hath forsake.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: I mean for preaching. I pray God thou be cursed.

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: no, no, with Judas we love well to be pursed.
we sell our maker so soon as we have him made,
And as for preaching we meddle not with that trade
lest Annas, Cayphas, and the lawyers should us blame,
Calling us to a reckoning for preaching in that name.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: But tell to me, person, why wert thou cast in prison?

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: for no great matter but a little petty treason:
for conjuring, caulking, and coining of new groats,
for clipping of nobles with such like praty motes.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: this is high treason and hath been evermore.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: It is such treason as he shall sure hang for.

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: I have holy orders. by the mass, I defy your worst
Ye cannot touch me but ye must be accursed.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: we will not touch thee, the halter shall do it alone.
Curse the rope therefore when thou beginnest to groan.

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: And set ye no more by the holy order of priesthood?
Ye will prove yourself an heretic by the rode.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Come hither, England, and hear what I say to thee.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: I am all ready to do as ye command me.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: for so much as he hath falsified our coin,
As he is worthy let let him with an halter join.
Thou shalt hang no priest nor yet none honest man,
But a traitor, a thief, and one that little good can.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: What, yet against the Church? Get me book, belle, and candle;
As I am true priest I shall ye yet better handle.
Ye neither regard his crown nor anointed fingers,
The office of a priest, nor the grace that therein lingers.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Sir, patient yourself and all thing shall be well.
Fie man to the Church that ye should be still a rebel.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: I accompt him no priest that work such heinous treason.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: It is a world to hear a foolish woman reason.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: After this manner ye used Peter Pomfrete,
A good simple man, and as they say, a profit.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Sir, I did prove him a very superstitious wretch
And blasphemous liar; therefore did the law him upstretch.
He prophesied first I should reign but fourteen years,
Making the people to believe he could bind bears;
And I have reigned a seventeen years and more.
And anon after he grudged at me very sore,
And said I should be exiled out of my realm
Before the ascension which was turned to a fantastical dream
Saying he would hang if his prophecy were not true.
Thus his own decay his foolishness did brew.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Ye should not hang him which is a friend to the Church.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Alas, that ye should count them friends of the Church
that against all truth so hypocritically lurch;
And ill Church is it that hath such friends in deed.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Of Master Morres such another fable we read,
that in Morgan's field the soul of a knight made verses,
Appearing unto him and this one he rehearses:

l.foreign: Destruet hoc regnum rex regum duplici plaga,

sp.l: Which is true as God spake with the Ape at Praga.
The souls departed from this heavy mortal pain
to the hands of God returneth never again.
A marvellous thing that ye thus delight in lies

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: this quean doth not else but mock our blessed stories.
that Peter angered ye when he called ye a devil incarnate.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: He is now full sure no more so uncomely to prate.
Well, as for this man, because that he is a priest
I give him to ye; do with him what ye list.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: in the Popes behalf I will somewhat take upon me.
Here I deliver him by the Churches liberty
in spite of your heart. Make of it what ye list.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: I am pleased, I say, because he is priest.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Whether ye be or no it shall not greatly force.
Let me see those chains. Go thy way, and have remorse.

sp.speaker: Treason
sp.l: God save your lordships. I trust I shall amend
And do no more so, or else, sir, God defend.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I shall make thee, I trow, to keep thy benefice.
by the Mary Mass, the knave will never be wise.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: like lord, like chaplain; neither barrel, better hearing.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Still she must trattle; that tongue is always stirring.
A word or two, sir, I must tell you in your ear.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Of some advantage I would very gladly hear.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Release not England of the general interdiction
Till the king hath granted the dowry and the pension
Of Julyane, the wife of King Richarde Cour the Lyon.
Ye know very well she beareth the Church good mind.
Tush, we must have all, man, that she shall leave behind.
As the saying is he findeth that surely bind.
It were but folly such loose ends for to lose.
The land and the money will make well for our purpose.
Tush, lay yokes upon him, more than he is able to bear;
Of Holy Church so he will stand ever in fear.
Such a shrew as he it is good to keep under awe.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Woo is that person which is underneath your law
Ye may see, good people, what these same merchants are,
Their secrete knaveries, their open facts declare.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Hold thy peace, callet, God give thee sorrow and care

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Ere I release you of the interdiction hear
in the which your realm continued hath this seven year,
Ye shall make Julyane your sister in law, this band,
to give her the third part of England and of Ireland.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: All the world knoweth, sir, I owe her no such duty.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Ye shall give it to her, there is no remedy.
Will ye still withstand our Holy Fathers precept?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: in pain of damnation his commandment must be kept.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: o, ye undo me considering my great payments.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Sir, discomfort not, for God hath sent debatements;
Your merciful maker hath showed upon ye his power,
From this heavy yoke delivering you this hour.
The woman is dead; such news are hither brought.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: for me a sinner this miracle hath God wrought.
in most high perils he ever me preserved,
And in this danger he hath not from me swerved.
As David saith, Lord, thou dost not leave thy servant
that will trust in thee and in thy blessed covenant.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: A vengeance take it by the mass, it is unhappy
She is dead so soon: now is it past remedy.
so must we lose all now that she is clearly gone.
If that pray had been ours, o, it had been alone
The chance being such, by my troth, even let it go.
no groat, no Pater Noster no penny, no placebo
The devil go with it saying it will be no better.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Their minds are all set upon the filthy lucre.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Then here I release you of your interdictions all,
And straightly command you upon dangers that may fall
No more to meddle with the Churches reformation,
Nor hold men from Rome when they make appellation
by God and by all the contents of this book.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Against Holy Church I will no more speak nor look.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Go, open the church doors, and let the bells be rung,
And through out the realm see that Te Deum be sung.
Prick up your candles before Saint Loe and Saint Legearde,
Let Saint Antony's hog be had in some regard.
If your ale be sour and your bread mould, certain,
Now will they wax sweet, for the Pope hath blessed ye again.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Then within a while I trust ye will preach the Gospel.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: that shall I tell thee, keep thou it in secrete counsel:
It shall neither come in church nor yet in chancel.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Goo your ways apace and see our pleasure be done.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: As ye have commanded all shall be performed soon.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: by the mass, I laugh to see this clean conveyance
He is now full glad as our pipe goeth to dance.
by cock's soul he is now become a good parish clarke.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Ha, ha, wily whoreson, dost that so busily mark?
I hope in a while we will make him so to rave
that he shall become unto us a common slave
And shall do nothing but as we bid him do.
If we bid him slay, I trow he will do so;
If we bid him burn such as believe in Christ
He shall not say nay to the bidding of a priest.
But yet it is hard to trust what he will be,
He is so crabbed, by the Holy Trinity.
to save all things up I hold best we make him more sure
And give him a sauce that he no longer endure.
Now that I remember we shall not leave him thus.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Why, what shall we do to him else, in the name of Jesus?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Marry fetch in Lewes, King Phylyppes son of France,
to fall upon him with his men and ordinance,
With wildfire, gunpowder, and such like miry tricks,
to drive him to hold and search him in the quicks.
I will not leave him till I bring him to his end.

sp.speaker: Cardynall
sp.l: Well, farewell Sedition; do as shall lie in thy mind.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I marvel greatly where Dissimulation is.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: I will come anon, if thou tarry till I piss.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I beshrew your heart Where have ye been so long?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: in the garden, man, the herbs and weeds among,
And there have I got the poison of toad.
I hope in a while to work some feat abroad.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I was wont sometime of thy privy counsel to be,
Am I now adays become a stranger to thee?

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: I will tell thee all underneath benedicte
What I mind to do in case thou wilt assoil me.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Thou shalt be assoiled by the most Holy Fathers authority.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Shall I so in deed? by the mass then now have at thee
benedicte.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: In nomine Papae, Amen.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Sir, this is my mind: I will give King Johan this poison,
so making him sure that he shall never have foison.
And this must thou say to colour with the thing
that a penny loaf he would have brought to a shilling.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Nay, that is such a lie as easily will be felt.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Tush, man, among fools it never will be out smelt,
Though it be a great lie. Set upon it a good face,
And that will cause men believe it in every place.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I am sure then thou wilt give it him in a drink.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Marry, that I will, and the one half with him swink
to encourage him to drink the bottom off.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: If thou drink the half thou shalt find it no scoff;
Of terrible death thou wilt stacker in the plashes.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Tush, though I die, man, there will rise more of my ashes.
I am sure the monks will pray for me so bitterly
that I shall not come in hell nor in purgatory.
in the Popes kitchen the scullions shall not brawl
Nor fight for my grease. If the priests would for me yowl
And grunt a good pace placebo with Requiem Mass,
Without much tarriance I should to paradise pass
Where I might be sure to make good cheer and be miry
for I cannot away with that whoreson purgatory.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: to keep thee from thence thou shalt have five monks singing
in Swynsett abbey so long as the world is during;
They will daily pray for the soul of Father Symon,
A Cistercian monk which poisoned King John.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: When the world is done what help shall I have then?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Then shift for thyself so well as ever thou can.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Cock's soul, he cometh here Assoil me that I were gone then.

l.foreign: Ego absolvo te, in nomine Papae, Amen.

body.stage: Exeunt Sedition and Dissimulation.Enter King John and England.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: no prince in the world in such captivity
As I am this hour, and all for righteousness.
Against me I have both the lords and commonalty,
Bishop's and lawyers, which in their cruel madness
Hath brought in hither the French kings eldest son, Lewes.
The chance unto me is not so dolorous,
But my life this day is much more tedious.
More of compassion for shedding of Christen blood
Than anything else my sceptre I gave up lately
to the Pope of Rome which hath no title good
Of jurisdiction but of usurpation only.
And now to the, Lord, I would resign up gladly
Both my crown and life, for thine own right it is
If it would please thee to take my soul to thy bliss.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Sir, discomfort ye not in the honour of Christ Jesu:
God will never fail you, intending not else but virtue.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: The anguish of spirit so pangeth me every where
that incessantly I thirst till I be there.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Sir, be of good cheer, for the Pope hath sent a legate
Whose name is Gualo, your foes to excommunicate.
Not only Lewes, which hath won Rochestre,
Wynsore and London, Readynge and Wynchestre,
But so many else as against ye have rebelled
He hath suspended and openly accursed.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: They are all false knaves; all men of them be ware.
They never left me till they had me in their snare.
Now have they Otto, the Emperor, so well as me
And the French king, Phylypp, under their captivity.
All Christen princes they will have in their bands.
The Pope and his priests are poisoners of all lands.
All Christen people be ware of traitorous priests
for of truth they are the pernicious Antichrists.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: this same Gualo, sir, in your cause doth stoutly bark.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: They are all naught, England, so many as wear that mark.
From this habitation, sweet lord, deliver me,
And preserve this realm, of thy benignity.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Wassail, wassail, out of the milk pail,
Wassail, wassail, as white as my nail,
Wassail, wassail, in snow, frost, and hail,
Wassail, wassail, with partridge and rail.
Wassail, wassail, that much doth avail,
Wassail, wassail, that never will fail.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: who is that, England? I pray thee, step fourth and see.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: He doth seem afar some religious man to be.

body.stage: Enter Dissimulation disguised as a monk.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Now Jesus preserve your worthy and excellent grace,
for doubtless there is a very angelic face.
Now forsooth and God, I would think myself in heaven
If I might remain with you but years eleven;
I would covet here none other felicity.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: A loving person thou mayest seem for to be.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: I am as gentle a worm as ever ye see.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: But what is thy name, good friend? I pray thee tell me.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Simon of Swynsett my very name is, per Dee.
I am taken of men for monastical devotion,
And here have I brought you a marvellous good potion
for I heard ye say that ye were very dry.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: in deed I would gladly drink. I pray thee, come nigh.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: The days of your life never felt ye such a cup,
so good and so wholesome if ye would drink it up.
It passeth malmsey, caprice, tire or ypocras.
by my faith, I think a better drink never was.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Begin, gentle monk; I pray thee, drink half to me.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: If ye drunk all up it were the better for ye.
It would slake your thirst and also quicken your brain.
A better drink is not in Portyngale nor Spain.
Therefore sup it of and make an end of it quickly.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Nay thou shalt drink half. There is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: Good luck to ye than; have at it by and by.
half will I consume if there be no remedy.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: God saint thee, good monk, with all my very heart.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: I have brought ye half; conveye me that for your part.
Where art thou, Sedition? by the mass, I die, I die.
Help now at a pinch. Alas, man, come away shortly

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Come hither apace and get thee to the farmery.
I have provided for thee, by sweet Saint Powle.
Five monks that shall sing continually for thy soul.
that, I warrant thee, thou shalt not come in hell.

sp.speaker: Dissymulacyon
sp.l: to send me to heaven goo ring the holy belle
And sing for my soul a mass of Scala Celi
that I may climb up aloft with Enoch and Heli.
I do not doubt it but I shall be a saint;
Provide a guilder mine image for to paint.
I die for the Church with Thomas of Canterbury.
Ye shall fast my vigil and upon my day be merry.
no doubt but I shall do miracles in a while,
And therefore let me be shrined in the north isle.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: to thee then will offer both cripple, halt and blind,
Mad men and mesels, with such as are woo behind.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: My body me vexeth; I doubt much of a timpani.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Now alas, alas, your grace is betrayed cowardly

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Where became the monk that was here with me lately?

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: He is poisoned, sir, and lieth adying surely.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: It cannot be so, for he was here even now.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Doubtless, sir, it is so true as I have told you.
A false Judas kiss he hath given you and is gone.
The halt, sore and lame this pitiful case will moan.
Never prince was there that made to poor peoples uses
so many masendewes, hospitals, and spittle houses
As your grace hath done yet since the world began.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Of priests and of monks I am counted a wicked man
for that I never built church nor monastery,
But my pleasure was to help such as were needy.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: The more grace was yours for at the day of judgment
Christ will reward them which hath done his commandment.
There is no promise for voluntary works
No more than there is for sacrifice of the Turks.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Doubtless I do feel much grievance in my body.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: As the Lord well knoweth for that I am full sorry.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: There is no malice to the malice of the clergy.
Well, the Lord God of heaven on me and them have mercy.
for doing justice they have ever hated me.
They caused my land to be excommunicate
And me to resign both crown and princely dignity,
From my obedience assoiling every estate,
And now, last of all, they have me intoxicate.
I perceive right well their malice hath none end.
I desire not else but that they may soon amend.
I have sore hungered and thirsted righteousness
for the office sake that God hath me appointed;
But now I perceive that sin and wickedness
in this wretched world, like as Christ prophesied,
Have the overhand; in me is it verified.
Pray for me, good people, I beseech you heartily,
that the Lord above on my poor soul have mercy.
Farewell, noble men, with the clergy spiritual;
Farewell, men of law, with the whole commonalty.
Your disobedience I do forgive you all
And desire God to pardon your iniquity.
Farewell, sweet England, now last of all to thee;
I am right sorry I could do for thee no more.
Farewell once again, yea, farewell for evermore.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: With the leave of God I will not leave ye thus,
But still be with ye till he do take you from us,
And then will I keep your body for a memorial.

sp.speaker: K.Johan
sp.l: Then ply it England, and provide for my burial.
A widow's office it is to bury the dead.

sp.speaker: Englande
sp.l: Alas, sweet master, ye weigh so heavy as lead.
o horrible case that ever so noble a king
should thus be destroyed and lost for righteous doing
by a cruel sort of disguised blood suppers,
Unmerciful murtherers all drunk in the blood of martyrs.
Report what they will in their most furious madness,
Of this noble king much was the godliness.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: I assure ye, friends, let men write that they will
King Johan was a man both valiant and godly.
What though Polydorus reporteth him very ill
At the suggestions of the malicious clergy?
Think you a Roman with the Romans cannot lie?
Yes Therefore Leylande out of thy slumber awake
And witness a truth for thine own country's sake.
for his valiantness many excellent writers make,
As Sigebertus, Vincentius and also Nauclerus;
Giraldus and Mathu Parys with his noble vertues take
Yea, Paulus Phrigio, Johan Major and Hector Boethius.
Nothing is allowed in his life of Polydorus
Which discommendeth his punishments for traitory,
Advancing very sore high treason in the clergy.
Of his godliness thus much report will I:
Gracious provision for sore, sick, halt and lame
He made in his time he made both in town and city
Granting great liberties for maintenance of the same
by markets and fairs in places of notable name.
Great monuments are in Yppeswych, Donwych and Berye,
Which noteth him to be a man of notable mercy.
The city of London through his mere grant and premye
Was first privileged to have both mayor and shrive,
Where before his time it had but bailiffs only.
in his days the bridge the citizens did contrive.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: Though he now be dead, his noble acts are alive.
his zeal is declared as touching Christ's religion
in that he exiled the Jews out of this region.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: whom speak ye of, sir, I beseech ye heartily?

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: I talk of King Johan, of late your prince most worthy.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Sir, he was a man of a very wicked sort.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: Ye are much to blame your prince so to report.
How can ye presume to be called Nobility
Defaming a prince in your malignity?
Ecclesiastes saith, If thou with an hateful heart
Misnamest a king thou playest such a wicked part
As birds of air to God will represent
to thy great apparel and exceeding punishment.
Saint Hierome saith also that he is of no renown
But a vile traitor that rebelleth against the crown.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: He speaketh not against the crown but the man, per dee.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: o, where is the spirit which ought to reign in thee
The crown of itself without the man is nothing.
Learn of the scriptures to have better understanding.
The heart of a king is in the hands of the Lord,
And he directeth it, wise Solomon to record.
They are abominable that use him wickedly.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: He was never good to us, the sanctified clergy.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: Will ye know the cause before this worshipful company?
Your conversation and lives are very ungodly.
King Solomon saith, who hath a pure mind,
Therein delighting shall have a king to friend.
on this word Cleros which signifieth a lot
Or a sorting out into a most godly knot,
Ye do take your name for that ye are the lords
Select of his word to be the special records,
As of Saint Mathias we have a singular mention
that they chose him out anon after Christ's ascension.
Thus do ye reckon. But I fear ye come of Clerus
A very noyfull worm, as Aristotle showeth us,
by whom are destroyed the honeycombs of bees;
for poor widows ye rob as did the Pharisees.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: I promise you it is uncharitably spoken.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: Truth engendereth hate; ye show thereof a token.
Ye are such a man as ought every where to see
A godly order, but ye lose each mare commonalty.
Plato thought always that no higher love could be
Than a man to pain himself, for his own country.
David for their sake the proud Philistine slew,
Aioth mad Eglon his wickedness to rue,
Esdras from Persye for his own country's sake
Came to Jerusalem their strong holds up to make;
But you like, wretches, cast over both country and king.
All manhood shameth to see your unnatural doing.
Ye wicked rulers, God doth abhor ye all.
As Mantuan reporteth in his Eclogues Pastoral
Ye feed not the sheep, but ever ye pile the flock
And clip them so nigh that scarcely ye leave one lock.
Your judgments are such that ye call to God in vain
so long as ye have your princes in disdain.
Chrysostome reporteth that nobility of friends
Availeth nothing except ye have godly minds.
What profiteth it you to be called spiritual
While you for lucre from all good vertues fall?
What praise is it to you to be called Civility
If you from obedience and godly order flee?
Anneus Seneca hath this most provable sentence:
The gentle free heart goeth never from obedience.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Sir, my brethren and I would gladly know your name.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: I am Veritas that come hither you to blame
for casting away of our most lawful king.
Both God and the world detesteth your damnable doing.
How have ye used King Johan here now of late
I shame to rehearse the corruptions of your state.
Ye were never well till ye had him cruelly slain,
And now, being dead ye have him still in disdain.
Ye have raised up of him most shameless lies
Both by your reports and by your written stories.
He that slew Saul through fierceness violent
Was slain soon after at David's just commandment
for because that Saul was anointed of the Lord.
The Second of Kings of this beareth plenteous record.
He was in those days esteemed worthy to die
on a nointed king that laid hands violently.
Ye are not ashamed to find five priests to sing
for that same traitor that slew your natural king.
A traitorous knave ye can set up for a saint,
And a righteous king like an hateful tyrant paint.
I could show the place where you most spitefully
Put out your torches upon his physiognomy.
in your glass windows ye whip your natural kings.
As I said afore, I abhor to show your doings.
The Turks I dare say are a thousand times better than you.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: for Gods love, no more Alas, ye have said enough.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: All the world doth know that we have done sore amiss.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Forgive it us so that we never hear more of this.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: But are ye sorry for this ungodly work?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I pray to God, else I be damned like a Turk.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: And make true promise ye will never more do so?

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Sir, never more shall I from true obedience goo.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: What say you, brother? I must have also your sentence.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: I will ever give to my prince due reverence.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: Well, then, I doubt not but the Lord will condescend
to forgive you all, so that ye mind to amend.
Adieu to ye all, for now I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Abide, Verity; ye shall not depart so soon.
Have ye done all things as we; commanded you?

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: Yea, most gracious prince, I concluded the whole even now.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: And how do they like the customs they have used
With our predecessors, whom they have so abused,
Specially King Johan? Think they they have done well?

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: They repent that ever they followed sedicious counsel
And have made promise they will amend all faults.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: And forsake the Pope with all his cruel assaults?

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: why do ye not bow to Imperial Majesty?
Kneel and ask pardon for your great enormity.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Most godly governor, we axe your gracious pardon,
Promising nevermore to maintain false Sedition.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: neither Private Wealth nor yet Usurped Power
Shall cause me disobey my prince from this same hour.
False Dissimulation shall never me beguile;
Where I shall mete him I will ever him revile.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: I perceive, Verity, ye have done well your part
Reforming these men. Gramercies with all my heart
I pray you, take pains to call our Commonalty
to true obedience as ye are Gods Verity.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: I will do it, sir. Yet shall I have much ado
With your Popish prelates. They will hunt me to and fro.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: so long as I live they shall do you no wrong.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: Then will I go preach Gods word your commons among.
But first I desire you their stubborn facts to remit.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: I forgive you all and pardon your froward wit.

sp.speaker: Omnes Una
sp.l: The heavenly governor reward your goodness for it.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: for Gods sake obey like as doth you befall,
for in his own realm a king is judge over all
by Gods appointment, and none may him judge again
But the Lord himself. in this the scripture is plain.
He that condemneth a king condemneth God without doubt
He that harmeth a king to harm God goeth about;
He that a prince resisteth doth damn Gods ordinance
And resisteth God in withdrawing his affiance.
All subjects offending are under the kings judgment:
A king is reserved to the Lord Omnipotent.
He is a minister immediate under God,
Of his righteousness to execute the rod.
I charge you therefore as God hath charge me
to give to your king his due supremity
And exile the Pope this realm for evermore.

sp.speaker: Omnes Una
sp.l: we shall gladly do according to your lore.

sp.speaker: Veritas
sp.l: Your grace is content I show your people the same?

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Yea, gentle Verity, show them their duty in Gods Name.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: to confirm the tale that Verity had now
The Second of Kings is evident to you.
The young man that brought the crown and bracelet
Of Saul to David, saying that he had him slain
David commanded as though he had done that forfeit
Straight way to be slain. Gods spirit did him constrain
to show what it is a kings blood to distain.
so did he those two that in the field him met
And unto him brought the head of Isboset.
Consider that Christ was under the obedience
Of worldly princes so long as he was here,
And always used them with a lowly reverence
Paying them tribute, all his true servants to steer
to obey them, love them, and have them in reverent fear.
damnation it is to him that an order break
Appointed of God, like as the Apostle speak.
no man is exempt from this Gods ordinance
Bishop, monk, canon, priest, cardinal, nor pope.
All they by Gods law to kings owe their allegiance.
this will be well known in this same realm, I hope.
Of Verity's words the sincere meaning I grope;
He saith that a king is of God immediately.
Then shall never pope rule more in this monarchy.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: If it be your pleasure we will exile him clean,
that he in this realm shall nevermore be seen,
And your grace shall be the supreme head of the Church.
to bring this to pass ye shall see how we will worship.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Here is a nice tale He saith, if it be my pleasure
He will do this act to the Popes most high displeasure,
As who saith, I would for pleasure of my person
And not for Gods truth have such an enterprise done.
Full wisely conveyed The crow will not change her hue.
It is marvel to me if ever ye be true.
I will the authority of Gods holy word to do it
And it not to arise of your vain slipper wit.
that scripture doth not is but a light fantasy.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Both Daniel and Paule calleth him Gods adversary,
And therefore ye ought as a devil him to expel.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Knew ye this afore and would it never tell?
Ye should repent it had we not now forgiven ye.
Nobility, what say you? Will ye to this agree?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I can no less, sir, for he is worse than the Turk.
Which none other ways but by tyranny doth work.
this bloody butcher with his pernicious bait
Oppress Christen princes by fraud, craft and deceit,
Till he compel them to kiss his pestilent fete
like a leviathan sitting in Moyses seat.
I think we can do unto God no sacrifice
that is more accept nor more agreeing to justice
Than to slay that beast and slaughterman of the devil,
that Babylon boar which hath done so much evil.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: It is a clear sign of a true nobility
to the word of God when your conscience doth agree.
for as Christ did say to Peter, Caro et sanguis

l.foreign: Non revelavit tibi,sed Pater meus celestis:

sp.l: Ye have not this gift of carnal generation,
Nor of noble blood, but by Gods own demonstration.
Of you, Civil Order, one sentence would I hear.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: I rue it that ever any heart I did him bear.
I think he hath sprung out of the bottomless pitt
And in men's conscience in the stead of God doth sit,
Blowing fourth a swarm of grasshoppers and flies
Monks, friars and priests, that all truth putrefies.
Of the Christen faith play now the true defender;
Exile this monster and ravenous devourer
With his venom worms, his adders, whelps and snakes,
his cuckolded vermin that unto all mischief wakes.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Then in this purpose ye are all of one mind?

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: we detest the Pope and abhor him to the find.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: And are well content to disobey his pride?

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Yea, and his lousy laws and decrees to set aside.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Then must ye be sworn to take me for your head.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: we will obey you as our governor in Gods stead.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Now that ye are sworn unto me your principal
I charge ye to regard the word of God over all
And in that alone to rule, to speak, and to judge,
As ye will have me your succour and refuge.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: If ye will make sure ye must exile Sedition,
False Dissimulation, with all vain superstition,
And put Private Wealth out of the monasteries;
Then Usurped Power may goo abirding for flies.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Take you it in hand and do your true diligence,
Each man for his part; ye shall want no assistance.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I promise you here to exile Usurped Power
And your supremity to defend each day and hour.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I promise also out of the monasteries
to put Private Wealth and detect his mysteries.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: False Dissimulation I will hang up in Smythfylde
With such superstition as your people hath beguiled.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Then I trust we are at a very good conclusion
Virtue to have place and vice to have confusion.
Take Verity with ye for every act ye do;
so shall ye be sure not out of the way to goo.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Peep I see ye I am glad I have spied ye.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: There is Sedition. Stand you aside a while;
Ye shall see how we shall catch him by a wile.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: no noise among ye? Where is the merry cheer
that was wont to be with quashing of double beer?
The world is not yet as some men would it have.
I have been abroad and I think I have played the knave.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Thou canst do none other except thou change thy wont.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: What mischief ail ye that ye are to me so blunt?
I have seen the day ye have favoured me, Perfection.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Thyself is not he; thou art of an other complexion.
Sir, this is the thief that first subdued King John,
Vexing other princes that since have ruled this region;
And now he doth prate he hath so played the knave
that the world is not yet as some men would it have.
It would be known, sir, what he hath done of late.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: What is thy name, friend? to us here intimate.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: A sanctuary A sanctuary for Gods dear passion, a sanctuary.
Is there none will hold me and I have made so many?

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Tell me what thy name is; thou playest the knave I trow.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I am windless, good man; I have much pain to blow.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: I say tell thy name or the rack shall thee constrain.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Holy Perfection my godmother called me plain.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: It is Sedition. God give him a very mischief

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Under heaven is not a more detestable thief.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: by the mass, ye lie. I see well ye do not know me.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Ah, brother, art thou come? I am right glad we have the.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: by body, blood, bones, and soul I am not he.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: If swearing might help he would do well enough.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: He scape not our hands so lightly, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: this is that thief, sir, that all Christendom hath troubled
And the Pope of Rome against all kings maintained.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: Now that ye have him no more but hang him up

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: If ye so be content it shall be done ere I sup.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Lo, the Clergy accuseth thee; Nobility condemneth thee;
And the law will hang thee. What sayst now to me?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I would I were now at Rome, at the sign of the cup,
for heaviness is dry. Alas, must I needs climb up?
Pardon my life and I shall tell ye all,
Both that is past and that will hereafter fall.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Arise. I pardon thee so that thou tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I will tell to you such treason as ensueth;
Yet a ghostly father ought not to bewray confession.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: no confession is but aught to discover treason.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I think it may keep all thing save heresy.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: It may hold no treason I tell thee verily,
And therefore tell the whole matter by and by.
Thou saidest now of late that thou hadst played the knave
And that the world was not as some men would it have.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I could play Pasquyll but I fear to have rebuke.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: for uttering the truth fear neither bishop nor duke.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Ye gave injunctions that Gods word might be taught,
But who observe them? Full many a time have I laughed
to see the conveyance that prelates and priests can find.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: And why do they bear Gods word no better mind?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: for if that were known then would the people regard
no head but their prince; with the Church then were it hard.
Then should I lack help to maintain their estate,
As I attempted in the North but now of late.
And since that same time in other places beside
Till my setters on were of their purpose wide.
A vengeance take it It was never well with me
Since the coming hither of that same Verity.
Yet do the bishops for my sake vex him among

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Do they so in deed? Well, they shall not do so long.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: in your parliament command you what ye will,
The Popes ceremonies shall drown the the Gospel still.
Some of the bishops at your injunctions sleep,
Some laugh and go by and some can play boo peep;
Some of them do naught but search for heretics
Whilst their priests abroad do play the schismatics.
Tell me in London how many their oaths discharge
Of the curates there? Yet is it much worse at large.
If your true subjects impugn their treacheries
They can fetch them in anon for sacramentaries
Or Anabaptists; thus find they a subtle shift
to prop up their kingdom such is their wily drift.
Get they false witnesses they force not of whence they be,
Be they of Newgate or be they of the Marshall see.
Paraventure a thousand are in one bishop's book
And against a day are ready to the hook.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Are those matters true that thouhast spoken here?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: What can in the world more evident witness bear?
First of all consider the prelates do not preach
But persecute those that the Holy Scriptures teach;
And mark me this well they never punish for popery
But the Gospel readers they handle very coarsely,
for on them they lay by hundred pounds of iron
And will suffer none with them once for to common.
Sit they never so long nothing by them cometh forth
to the truths furtherance that anything is worth.
in some bishop's house ye shall not find a testament,
But each man ready to devour the innocent.
we linger a time and look but for a day
to set up the Pope if the Gospel would decay.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Of that he hath told his self is the very ground.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: art thou of counsel in this that thouhast spoken?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Yea, and in more than that if all secretes might be broken;
for the Pope I make so much as ever I may do.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: I pray thee heartily, tell me why thou dost so.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: for I perceive well the Pope is a jolly fellow,
A trim fellow, a rich fellow, yea, and miry fellow.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: A jolly fellow how dost thou prove the Pope?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: for he hath cross keys with a triple crown and a cope,
Trim as a trencher, having his shoes of gold,
Rich in his royalty and angelic to behold.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: How dost thou prove him to be a fellow miry?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: He hath pipes and bells, with kyrie, kyrie, kyrie.
Of him ye may buy both salt, cream, oil and wax.
And after high mass ye may learn to bear the pax.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Yea, and nothing hear of the Epistle and the Gospel?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: no, sir, by the mass; he will give no such counsel.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: When thou art abroad where dost thy lodging take?

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Among such people as God did never make;
Not only cuckolds, but such as follow the Popes laws
in disguised coats with bald crowns like jack daws.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Then every where thou art the Popes altogether.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Ye had proved it ere this if I had not chanced hither
I sought to have served you like as I did King John,
But that Verity stopped me, the devil him poison

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: He is worthy to die and there were men no more.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Hang up the vile knave and keep him no longer in store.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: Draw him to Tyburne; let him be hanged and quartered.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: Why of late days ye said I should not so be martyred.
Where is the pardon that ye did promise me?

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: for doing more harm thou shalt soon pardoned be.
Have him fourth, Civil Order, and hang him till he be dead,
And on London Bridge look ye bestow his head.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: I shall see it done and return to you again.

sp.speaker: Sedicyon
sp.l: I beshrew your heart for taking so much pain.
Some man tell the Pope I beseech ye with all my heart,
How I am ordered for taking the Churches part,
that I may be put in the Holy Litany
With Thomas Beckett, for I think I am as worthy.
Pray to me with candles for I am a saint already.
O blessed Saint Partryck, I see thee, I, verily.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: I see by this wretch there hath been much fault in ye;
Show yourselves hereafter more sober and wise to be.
King Johan ye subdued for that he punished treason,
Rape, theft, and murther, in the holy spirituality.
But Thomas Beckett ye exalted without reason
Because that he died for the Churches wanton liberty,
that the priests might do all kinds of iniquity
And be unpunished. Mark now the judgment
Of your idle brains and for Gods love repent.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: As God shall judge me I repent me of my rudeness.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I am ashamed of my most vain foolishness.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: I consider now that God hath for Sedition
Sent punishments great. Examples we have in Brute,
in Catilyne, in Cassius, and fair Absalom,
whom of their purpose God always destitute,
And terrible plagues on them did execute
for their rebellion. And therefore I will be ware
lest his great vengeance trap me in such such like snare.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: I ponder also that since the time of Adam
The Lord evermore the governors preserved.
Examples we find in Noah and in Abraham,
in Moyses and David, from whom God never swerved.
I will therefore obey lest he be with me displeased.
Homerus doth say that God putteth fourth his shield
The prince to defend when he is in the field.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: this also I mark: when the priests had governance
Over the Hebrews the sects did first arise
As Pharisees, Sadducees and Essees, which wrought much grievance
Among the people by their most devilish practice,
Till destructions the princes did devise
to the quietness of their faithful commons all,
As your grace hath done with the sects papistical.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: that point hath in time fallen to your memories.
The Anabaptists, a sect new risen of late,
The scriptures poiseneth with their subtle allegories,
The heads to subdue after a sedicious rate.
The city of Mynster was lost through their debate.
They have here begone their pestilent seeds to sow,
But we trust in God to increase they shall not grow.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: God forbid they should for they might do much harm

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: we shall cut them short if they do hither swarm.

sp.speaker: Imperyall Majestye
sp.l: The administration of a princes governance
Is the gift of God and his high ordinance,
whom with all your power you three ought to support
in the laws of God to all his peoples comfort.
First you, the Clergy, in preaching of Gods word
Then you , Nobility, defending with the sword;
you, Civil Order in executing justice.
Thus I trust we shall seclude all manner of vice,
And after we have established our kingdom
in peace of the Lord and in his godly freedom,
we will confirm it with wholesome laws and decrees,
to the full suppressing of Antichrists vanities.
Farewell to ye all; first to you Nobility,
Then to you, Clergy, then to you, Civility;
And above all things remember our injunction.

sp.speaker: Omnes Una
sp.l: by the help of God each one shall do his function.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: by this example ye may see with your eyes
How Antichrists whelps have noble princes used.
again ye may see how they with prodigious lies
And crafts uncomely their mischiefs have excused.
Both nature, manhood, and grace they have abused,
Defiling the law, and blinding Nobility
no Christen region from their abusing free.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: Mark well the damnable bestowing of their masses
With their foundations for poisoning of their king.
Their confession drifts all other traitory passes.
A saint they can make of the most knave this day living,
Helping their market. And to promote the thing
He shall do miracles. But he that blemish their glory
Shall be sent to hell without any remedy.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Here was to be seen what riseth of Sedition
And how he doth take his maintenance and ground
Of idle persons brought up in superstition,
Whose daily practice is always to confound
Such as mindeth virtue and to them will not be bound.
Expedient it is to know their pestilent ways,
Considering they were so busy now of late days.

sp.speaker: Nobylyte
sp.l: England hath a queen, thanks to the Lord above,
Which be a light to other princes all
for the godly ways whom she doth daily move
to her liege people through Gods word special.
She is that Angel, as Saint Johan doth him call,
that with the Lords seal doth mark out his true servants.
Printing in their hearts his holy words and covenants.

sp.speaker: Clergye
sp.l: in Daniels spirit she hath subdued the Papists
With all the offspring of Antichrists generation;
And now of late days the sect of Anabaptists
She seeketh to suppress for their pestiferous fashion.
She vanquisheth also the great abomination
Of superstitions, witchcrafts and idolatry,
Restoring Gods honour to his first force and beauty.

sp.speaker: Cyvyle Order
sp.l: Pray unto the Lord that her grace may continue
The days of Nestor to our souls consolation;
And that her offspring may live also to subdue
The great Antichrist with his whole generation,
in Helias spirit to the comfort of this nation;
Also to preserve her most honourable counsel
to the praise of God and glory of the Gospel.

body.stage: Thus endeth the two playes of Kynge Johan.
